My second visit to Chef's Table and a reminder of why I consider it my favorite 3 Michelin. Chef Cesar takes quality ingredients and manage to perfectly balance them in his dishes. His uni and truffle toast is second to none. The toro tart was magical. The duck ravioli was a tease that left you wanting a bowl of it. And the frozen souffle was like eating a delicious cloud. 
I really can't say enough good things about Chef's Table. I will be back yet again.

Food/Dishes - superb, excellent, undeniably great!
Table/seating/space - a little cramped
Service - a little subpar for a 3-star spot, could be better
Overall experience - Good

Review titles: Best Food I Ever Eaten in my Life
Be prepared to be blown away!!!!

Review text: I have nothing but great things to say about the chefs table. Service on point, the food creative and tasty. One of the best !

A kind of weird entry through a grocery store lies one of New York’s best restaurants. Chef’s Table is a three Michelin-starred restaurant featuring the cuisine of Chef César Ramirez. Every dish was packed with flavour. There was not a single dish that we didn’t enjoy. The quality of food is also of high nature. Decor and atmosphere is simple but chic. Service was professional and attentive. The whole dining experience was flawless save for what happened at the end. Chef Ramirez was attending the tables and greeting his guests which is our usual gesture at high end restaurants and with well-known chefs. We were surprised that he didn’t pass by our table or greet us. We thought that he may do this towards the end. We asked for the bill and it was obvious that we were not going to meet him. So when we were leaving we asked the waiters every code great chef Ramirez. We were surprised to be told that he is busy in the kitchen doing the ice cream dish! No one even offered to check or ask us if we could wait for him. This left an impression with us at ignoring us was intentional and for reasons that we have no clue for. Obviously we were disappointed but this would not let me rate restaurant less than 5.

My, it must be hard to "outdo yourself" all the time. But Chef Ramirez and his team of chefs and attentive staff...well, they do, every time! Each forkful is heavenly....somehow making one a tad nervous that you won't get to enjoy the next. But...you do...and this glorious experience is somehow "shared" by those who are preparing it for you. "I see you glimpsing in my direction" sous chef's....and BRAVO!
I'll be back.....

Review titles: Best of all NYC 3 star Michelin Restaurants
To say that this is my favorite

Review text: Out of all the 3 Star Michelin restaurants in NYC, I have to say that this was the best. Different set up at the counter where you can see various chefs work together, which I found to be interesting and honest. Food quality in all the top restaurants is top notch. What really separate them really is the slight difference in taste. Chef Table presents each dish with perfect execution which creates incomparable taste. Definitely one of my favorites. Highly recommend people to experience what I went through last night.

Review titles: I was wrong, "this time was even better"!

Review text:
The 12 course menu of chef Ramirez is the meal I have ever had in NYC and the most expensive one. 
All dishes were exceptional, unique, tasteful and creative and amazingly you don’t feel heavy at the end.
The entrance from the supermarket is cool.

I can't say enough about our 14 course - unblievable - dining experience. There is definitely a reason that this place has a 3 Michelin rating. WOW!!!!! We sat at the counter! Highly recommend the counter. Every dish was different, challenging my senses, and ultimately unforgettable. Huge thank you to the chef for such a wonderful meal!

Coming in here I feel nothing but disappointment. Hate how they make me wear a jacket. They offer you a suit jacket if you don’t have one, but wearing their jacket would have ruined my evening,
If you want to really surprise your date, bring her here. The front door is literally that of a supermarket’s. Not a food market or fancy food court but literally a supermarket where you buy groceries. And not even a fancy supermarket either. Think neighborhood Keyfood. I believe they can easily move if they want from all the money they are making but it seems to me they enjoy this notoriety. While I don’t really care but the fact they made me dress up in a suit jacket and shoes really piss me off so I’m not laughing because the joke’s on me.
There is no waiting room. It’s better to even come late as most ppl do. Coming in early and you just have to stroll around the supermarket like a dope. Their limited seating forbids them to seat you early unless you’re the first group of the evening.
The bar is huge and I would say it’s better to eat at the bar because the tables are just in the peripheries. The main attraction is definitely the bar facing the kitchen. It’s fancy inside but not that fancy that would warrant a suit jacket. They really should consider removing that requirement along with shoes which I don’t like wearing. Why wear shoes when you can wear comfy casual canvas sneakers? I understand athletic sneakers might be too much, but who is looking at our feet when we are dining? The pretentiousness itself is enough to make me really mad and give them a bad review outright.
The drinks are another issue. Only wine. Pretty much there are no cheap drinks here like beer or soda since this is not included in the precharged price so they want to add another $200 to the already $400 cost. Ouch. Juice is cheapest at $10 or just water thru it.
I thought about removing a star or two but in the end, the food was not just amazing but the best I ever eaten ever. Pretty much every dish was a delight. And there were so many. At the end of the night, I was quite full and very happy.

The service can be stuffy at times and the smiles quite fake but they do their jobs. If you can overlook all the earlier grievances that I stated then it’s quite a spectacular meal for the evening.

Review titles: Excellent Taste/Flavor, Service could be better

Review text: To say that this is my favorite restaurant in all the world is an understatement. Were I to choose a last supper, this would be it. Chef César Ramirez controls all aspects of your dining experience. His waitstaff is incredibly capable and his ~15-course menu, undeniably perfect. I’ve dined at Chef’s Table, I venture a guess, about 30 times, both at his initial location in Brooklyn and now in Manhattan, both locations consistently over the top superb. Chef has amazing credentials having worked at Danube and Bouley before going solo at Chef’s Table. I have had the good fortune to have dined at many of the worlds best restaurants, Chef’s Table is my (long-standing) favorite, hands down!

Review titles: Their Michelin Star Should Be A Black Hole
Great Food But Attitude Needs Adjusting

Review text: We loved the small plates here and had a wonderful waitress. But the other staff was really snooty -- both obnoxious when seating us and pressuring us to leave. Expensive dining should feel more relaxing than this.

Review titles: Love the Food, Hate the Noise

Review text:
Very unique menu, friendly staff and great food.
Always a treat when in NYC, unlike most restaurants in town.
Good for dining with friends/ groups etc.

Was much smaller space than I expected, had heard rave reviews from family and press.Lamb ribs, fried rice, summer squash, beef tartare, etc. All nice and enjoyable, just didn't  amaze me like I had hoped.
We were recommended to go here otherwise I doubt we would have found it. Amazing dishes particularly the endive salad. Only disappointment the egg and bacon dish.

This was my third trip to this restaurant since it opened about six years ago. The food is still excellent and the noise still deafening. Love all of our dishes, particularly the burrata and ricotta dumplings. The foie gras was good too. The noise, however is so loud that it is unpleasant. Tables are a foot apart so that you can clearly hear your neighbors shouting at each other. A restaurant with such high quality food should do something about the environment in with it is served. It is a disservice to the food.

Great vibe - hip kind of feeling. Service was good and attentive, but relaxed.
Food very good, well priced and a lot of wine options. Can recommend!

This restaurant also fairly often ranks amongst world class restaurants in several lists we gave it a try for lunch/brunch.
The menu is quiet small, which is fine with us cause it seems very fresh and hand made.
Restaurant itself is not very fancy, has a certain hipster style - which we really liked- as you don't feel underdressed coming in normal clothes. In general it could be a bit more spacious, as the tables are very very small.
Service was pleasant - nothing very special for the States though. 
They forgot to serve us the drinks we ordered - but ok - happens everywhere.
Plates are meant to be shared. We shared three dishes. 
All dishes were good beyond any doubt. Nevertheless, we thought that prices are too high for the performance. The handmade pasta was the best dish and recommendable. The lamb was not that good in our opinion. Vert interesting and tasty seasoning, but simply not the best piece of lamb with lots of fat and tissue. 
The starter was good but by no means spectacular- we had lots of better Burrata for less money. 
Again it seems that the ranking of this restaurant mainly comes from it being in New York rather than being world class. 
Try it and judge on your own. 
We would try some other place the next time.

This place SUCKS!!!! I am embarrassed for myself that I chose to eat here earlier in the year. It took me so long to write this review as I really wanted to find the right vernacular to share this crappy experience, but once I saw that Michelin was smoking something to give these guys a star, I said screw it...I'll take one for the team and throw eloquence to the wind.

I was meeting a very dear friend after 4 years and chose to dine here thinking that it would be fuss-free and it had great critical reviews, landing on the Best 50 Restaurants in the 51-100 list. I don't know what Pellegrino is thinking either. I have dined all over the world and there are way better restaurants than this place. Nothing wrong with getting the food ordered - our server was pretty good in explaining the menu and how many entrees would be appropriate for the two of us. But once the food started to come out, I don't know what happened. For a Michelin/Best 50 restaurant, GET THE SERVICE RIGHT!!!! No replacement of the small appetizer plates unless we literally called the staff down, no asking of a replenishment of my water and no replacement of cutlery. The food kept coming out in haphazard fashion. We were told that the food would come out as it is prepared - which is fine - but receiving their critically-acclaimed dumplings 20 minutes after we are done eating everything else? Come on! 

As for the food...it's nothing. I don't even remember what I ate, maybe I choose to block it out of my brain. There is way better food out there - you could probably get better odds circling your finger on a map and pointing blind. Shame on the critics for pumping these guys up with undeserving accolades and not giving the spots to someone who actually deserves it.

I came to Estela per the recommendation of a friend. First, the 'restaurant' (should really be called a 'tapas place') is located at East Houston Street between Mulberry and Mott. It is not at an 'exclusive' location. Prepare to be shocked by the unfair portion to price equation: $17 cocktail, $26 black rice. The cocktail was not balanced (I'm still recovering from a headache) and the black rice was miniscule. If you are going for a meal, plan for a $120 budget, drinks excluded. This is simply disrespectful, especially given the size of everything in the menu. For those of us working in the arts/culture sector, Estela is simply a waste of money. Go for it if you are in the 'bling-bling' mood, but otherwise skip and head to any other decently priced and portioned restaurant. I can recommend Ruby's on Mulberry, a few blocks south, Cafe Gitane or Hakata Tonton in the Village. Avoid collaborating with the 1%.

I could spend paragraphs talking about the much hyped caviar dish and the amazing dishes. But I'm just going to share one experience regarding the ice cube...yes you read that right...the ice cube for the cocktails. So you order your drink and the bartender bends down, opens a fridge and takes out a huge square block of ice about the size of your palm. He places it on a huge wooden chopping block that's at least 3 inches thick. With a giant butcher knife, he begins to slice off the corners and edges. After half a dozen or so slices, he has carved what was once a square cube of ice into a diamond cut shape with multiple facets. That was something I've never seen before in my life!

We love fine Japanese cuisine and have eaten at many Japanese restaurants around the world ranging from so-so to excellent, but our evening at Uchu beat them all. It is Michelin starred, and rightfully so. This was a veritable gourmet experience. The restaurant is on a nondescript street in lower Manhattan. It consists of two small, intimate bars -- the eight-seat Kaiseki bar and the ten-seat Omakase Sushi Bar. We dined in the latter and will be forever grateful that we did. The décor is simple, but elegant in the Japanese fashion,
There is champagne with the opening course and after that the diners choose their beverages which range from fine French wines to elegant Japanese sakes. We chose the latter as the perfect accompaniment to our meal. A sommelier and his assistant stand ready at attention to refill one's glass which they do with quiet discretion. 
Reservations are a must. There are two sittings per evening, and Master Chef Eiji Ichimura prepares for everyone at the bar a series of raw and cooked mouthwatering gems of the freshest fishes with decorative, fragrant, and delicious greens and flowers. The flavors, textures, and colors are exquisitely varied.

This is not an evening to be taken lightly. The team at Uchu take their careers very seriously and do all they can to make sure your evening with them is a special one. From the tasting courses to the drink pairings, no detail is too small and no expense is spared.

Overall it's a top Japanese Kaiseki restaurant in NYC. It only serves 8 seats a time, so you need to book early, unless you're fine with its 9pm dining iteration. 
The food is a mixed style of western cuisine and Japanese Kaiseki. Some ingredients are not common in classic Japanese Kaiseki, such as caviar and toast bread. So if you are looking for real traditional and classic Japanese Kaiseki, you will found it's a bit disappointed. Since I've read reviews before I visited, my expectation is that I can taste something both westernized and Japanese. So I like their food.
The drink is also good. They have 3 small cocktails come with the Kaiseki, and I like all of them. They have a great selection of Japanese whisky, too. 
I give 4 stars because I'd like to see more classic Japanese ingredients in the menu.

Review titles: Just look at that Japanese whisky bar!

Review text:
I was told of Uchu by a complete stranger. He spoke of the atmosphere but also of the creativity of the people there and the created experience. If you are interested in one of the most unique dining experiences in NYC, try to get a reservation at Uchu.
Six seats, comfortable, well apportioned with a wonderful collection of glasses from Japan. The hosts are gentlemen, perfectionists, and knowledgeable. Chef -a genius.
Enjoy the tasting menu with the pairing. It is worth it -especially since most are not this is again unique.
A few featured items were a Siberian Sturgeon Caviar handroll - amazing. A lovely Aji dish, and an amazing Chilean Black Truffle and Foie Gras

We have enjoyed many kaiseki meals in Japan and the US, but Uchu was definitely one of our very best such dining experiences. The meal is served to guests seated around an eight-seat Japanese whiskey bar, which as adjacent to the better known Uchu sushi bar. The setting is very calm and relaxed and perfect for couples enjoying a special night out. (To avoid delaying your fellow diners, however, it is important to be punctual.) From the moment we arrived and were welcomed with a refreshing, light cocktail, the level of service was outstanding. Given the intimate nature of the bar we were able to discuss the menu and wine pairing in detail with the very knowledgeable sommelier. Our requests that one of us wanted a pescatarian meal and that certain foods were to be avoided were handled perfectly. The meal was truly spectacular. The menu loosely followed the traditional kaiseki format, but with some unusual, and highly successful twists such as the Osetra caviar temaki and the A5 Wagyu sandwich. We enjoyed every one of the 12 courses and felt that the optional wine pairings, a mixture of sakes, European wines and a Japanese whiskey, were well matched to the courses. Uchu Kaiseki Bar has only been in operation for two years or so, but has already been awarded a Michelin star. Based on our experience that rating can only go up.

Review titles: A mixed style of western cuisine and Japanese Kaiseki

Review text: First of all...I want to buy that chandelier in the entry way -- an electronic installation where at the ends of each of the spokes, instead of a real flame or light bulb, a tiny LED display shows an intentionally pixelated flame. Ok, on to the food...all kinds of yummy. But that was to be expected. What was a pleasant surprise: each dish also came with a card with the name of the artisan who crafted the unique bowls and plates the food came on. Another "gimmick" I loved -- at one point, guests are invited to choose from an array of individuatized chopsticks and knifes. I have to say...they did take the gimmicks a little too far with the cards detailing all the info surrounding each dish (history, inspiration, ingredients, source, blah blah). I think I could have done well with just the ingredients and source and maybe ONE line describing the inspiration but this was info overload. Other than that, a fantastic night.

So sad to not being writing a 5 star review. Atoboy is my wife and I's favorite restaurant in NYC right now and have been there many times. For context, we occasionally do high end tasting menus, like 2-5 a year.
I would reaaallly like to focus on all of the amazing things Atomix did, but unfortunately there was a fatal flaw - not serving a full meal! My wife is 100lbs and has only finished one tasting menu before, that was a $60 4 course menu downtown. We even had a huge breakfast at 1pm before the 6pm reservation. When we got to Atomix, she was worried that she was not even going to be able to taste 10 dishes. She said she was a 6 or 7 in hunger out of 10.
She ate every bite of food. Literally every bit of banchan. She also had all of the wine, which was also a first. (I think the wine pairings were phenomal though! Great sommelier choices). After the meal was over she said "should we go get some beer and fried chicken sandwiches?".
I'm normally a big eater, and will actually eat a snack before these long tasting menus, so I can enjoy the first courses with out being so hungry. I think i was exactly the same fullness after the meal as I was 2.5 hrs earlier. If my wife had said it was too much food for her, then I would probably have given 5 stars (and eaten her left overs). But, to serve a meal that is average sized for a 100lb woman to everyone is crazy. Yes, i would like a full meal for a 200lb adult for my $1,000, not just great tastes and an amazing experience. Even sprang for the extras!
I looked around and every bite was finished by everyone there. I don't know how this hasn't come up more in the reviews!?
The service, taste, decor, experience and wine pairings were 5 stars. I had been looking to come since they announced the restaurant over a year ago. Wish I could remember it for the experience instead of lack of calories.
Overall, just go to atoboy!

Review titles: Truly enjoyed eating here one of the highlights of my new York trip !

Review text:
My spouse and I dined at Atomix for dinner on a Saturday evening in early March 2019. Atomix (pronounced ah-TOE-mix) is open for dinner on Tuesdays through Saturdays (closed Sundays and Mondays). We booked our spot online one month in advance using the pre-paid Tock reservation system. (For example, March reservations became available on February 1; April reservations became available on March 1, and so on.) This very popular restaurant always sells out quickly. Using Tock (set up an account ahead of time, so that on the day you reserve, you can just select a day/time and press a button), you must pre-pay for the entire meal ($225 per person, which includes tax and gratuity). On the night that you dine, you pay separately for your beverages.
Atomix opened in 2018 in a townhouse on East 30th Street. Upon climbing the steps to the brownstone, we had a difficult time choosing which door to enter (there is no sign or mark indicating behind which door is the restaurant). After picking the correct door, we saw that the first floor contained a bar and lounge area that serves drinks and small plates; you can dine there without a reservation. Below street level (down an elegant set of stairs) is another small lounge area that adjoins the main dining room with its 14-seat rectangular black granite counter. Before being seated for dinner, guests first enjoy some drinks and small bites in a casual group setting, although we arrived too late to partake. Diners are invited to choose a set of chopsticks from the chef’s collection, and other serveware is handmade by artisans in South Korea. Prior to each course, a tunic-clad server places a card in front of each diner that contains a Korean word describing the dish. The back of the card lists the dish’s ingredients. At the end of the evening, the restaurant packages the cards together to take home as a unique souvenir.
Atomix is operated by a husband-and-wife team, JP and Ellia. He (formerly the chef de cuisine at Jungsik, where we dined in August 2017; see our separate review) is the chef, and she manages the front-of-house. The duo also operate the more casual Atoboy (pronounced ah-TOE-boy), located just two short blocks away. (We dined at Atoboy in October 2019; see our separate review.)
Atomix serves a Korean 10-course tasting menu. Before our meal, I ordered a drink called the Samioko, made with tequila, mezcal, grapefruit, lemon, and honey. There were three splashes of sesame oil on top, so when I sipped, I tasted sweetness and immediately smelled the sesame oil. It was ingenious! But onto the food …
• We first received two amuse bouche: a crispy shell filled with crudo and a miniature truffle tart.
• At this point, we were shown some enormous black truffles and asked whether we wanted to add them to any or all of 3 courses (two of them were Jjim [snow crab] and Jorim [wagyu]) for about $20 per plate; although the price seemed reasonable, we passed on the offer).
1. "Guk" – maesaengi (seaweed), garlic custard, uni, pork broth
2. "Hwe" (Raw)– yellowtail, carrot jang, chojang (sweet chili pepper sauce), perilla leaf
3. "Jeon" (Fried) – potato, fermented yuza, herbs, flowers (THIS WAS ONE OF MY FAVORITE COURSES)
4. "Jjim"(Steam) –snow crab, grandada pepper, trout roe, tapioca, white kimchi sauce (ANOTHER FAVORITE)
banchan: gyeranmari (a rolled omelette) with myeongran jeot cream (salted seafood) 
5. "Twigim" (Fried)– soondae (blood sausage), gim (seaweed), ssamjang (spicy) dip
banchan: mustard kimchi and cuttlefish
6. "Sukchae"(Blanched) – celeriac, buttermilk cheese, hazelnut milk, caviar
black rice (which looked purple) with sweet potatoes, ginger, chive (WE DIDN’T LOVE THE RICE SIDE DISH)
7. "Gui" (Grilled) –snapper, kohlrabi kimchi, nuruk sauce (ANOTHER FAVORITE)
banchan: parse (seaweed), dubu skin, wasabi (WE DIDN’T LOVE THIS BANCHAN)
8. "Jorim" (Braised) – wagyu, fermented red pepper, ginger leaf oil (YUMMO!)
rice: white rice with an assortment of lettuces to eat ssam style (wrapped) (WE LIKED THE UNIQUENESS OF THIS SIDE DISH BUT NOT NECESSARILY THE FLAVOR)
9. "Ipgasim" (palate cleanser)– makgeolli (rice wine ice cream), quince, pear, sumac meringue
10. "Husik" (Sweet/Dessert) – red bean paste, persimmon, pine nut (WE LOVED THIS BECAUSE WE HADN’T EXPECTED THE BEAN PASTE TO BE WARM)
We thoroughly enjoyed our dinner at Atomix; the food, atmosphere, and service were top-notch!

My daughter in law is Korean and when she came to New York City with my son earlier this year she ate at this establishment I believe it had just opened.
She insisted that when we go to New York we eat here too. What an excellent experience I really didn’t have any idea what to expect when I came here and the location was a little difficult for me to find.
The food however, the cocktails, the service was really excellent we were lucky we got a reservation because we booked one prior to leaving Australia. I don’t think we would’ve been able to get in if we tried once we arrived.
I have eaten extensively are different places in Korea and I can honestly say that Atomix top’s them all. 
We highly recommend this restaurant and suggest you make a booking, you will not be disappointed.

Review titles: One of the best dining experiences you'll ever have...
Distinguishes Itself from Other Chef’s Tasting Experiences

Review text:
I had no idea what to expect when I came here on my own after a recommendation by a friend. The restaurant is located in a discreet part of town, somewhere you would never expect a modern Korean fine dining restaurant to be. There are only has counter seats, which worked perfectly for solo diners like me. Special thanks to Ellia, the co-owner, who made me feel so welcome and comfortable throughout the meal!
I was honestly blown away by not only the attention to detail put into each and every dish (food presentation, use of ceramics from independent designers, information cards detailing the inspiration behind and composition of each dish), but also the way I was given a completely new perspective on the Korean food I knew growing up. Totally surreal experience of discovering new flavors like fermented truffle dashi, and salted sea cucumber innards sauces. Unique, experiential and delicious! I cannot wait for my next visit -- if I can even land a reservation with the amount of global media attention they're getting now!

Review titles: Set of new impressions of Korea

Review text:
My husband and I dined at the intimate Atomix last night. I am not at all familiar with Korean food and did not know what to expect. It was undoubtedly one of the best meals we have had - the perfect marriage of tastes and textures in each bite was sublime!
The very talented and understated chef JP Park creates ten unique, inspired courses, drawing from Korean ingredients and preparations. Only 14 diners are served at one time, around a u-shaped bar, with two seatings per evening. 
A beautiful card comes with each course, describing the ingredients and origins for the dish. I loved having the background information, although I must admit that many of the ingredients were unfamiliar to me. But the stories about the inspiration for each course were fascinating. 
Each course is also served on beautiful ceramic pieces. The artist’s name is listed on the cards. Diners also select a pair of chopsticks to use at the beginning of the meal. No attention to detail has been spared. 
To begin the meal, diners are given two appetizers (in addition to the ten courses). From the first bite, we knew it would be a special evening. I cannot begin to describe the courses ... several featured seafood including snow crab, caviar, yellowtail, and perhaps my favorite of the evening ... golden eye snapper, with its skin ever so delicately broiled to perfection, served with white kimchi juice and an incredible sauce of fish stock, cream, brown rice vinegar and ginger juice to name a few of the ingredients. Perfection!
There were two sweet courses to finish the meal, one featuring Makegeolli ice cream (from a Korean alcoholic beverage) and the other red bean, persimmon and pine nut. 
Descriptions don’t do the complex dishes justice. You need to be there to experience it. One sublime bite after the other ...
The wait staff feels like family - welcoming and knowledgeable. Ellia Park quietly oversees the dining area. No fuss, no drama, just one truly incredible meal. 
The menu changes quarterly and we will definitely be back for the spring menu!
Thank you to the whole Atomix team for an incredible evening!

Review titles: Favorite and most unique part of my NYC food trip
Excellent food, amazing presentation and service

Review text: Every opportunity latent in the tasting-menu format is brought out and turned to advantage by Atomix, where each course comes with a flash card that builds your understanding of Korean ingredients and culture. At the end of the night, you have a full deck and a set of new impressions of Korea, too.

Getting a reservation here is difficult. You have to get it a month out and fully pay for it though Tock. So needless to say, I've been trying to get a reservation here for a long while. So when I finally got one, I was super excited. 

Let's talk location. It's not far off from ktown and hidden in a residential area. In fact, you may even ring the wrong doorbell. Looking for the Ring smart doorbell and you'll find the correct location. 

You'll be greeted by the hostess and you'll walk through the very modern looking bar. Then you'll proceed down the stairs to the waiting area. The entire space is very reminiscent of your rich friend's loft apartment. 

If you arrive on time, you'll receive your first two snacks in the lounge while you wait for your table. You're seated in a horseshoe shaped bar with generous space in between parties. 

The coursed meal comes out pretty quickly but doesn't feel rushed. Overall the food was unique modern Korean. There were a few misses but overall flavorful. It reminded me a bit of Copenhagen cuisine. 

I think my overall assessment was that it was good but not amazing. I see the appeal but wouldn't necessarily want to go back. The overall experience was great but the food is why I eat out.

Wow! We picked Atomix based on a great NYT review and were not disappointed. The layout of the dining area and the overall flow of the tasting menu were similar to those of Momofuku Ko, but the vibe at Atomix was less theatrical and more personal. Each dish was a tasty work of art, and the (optional) wine pairing complemented the dishes very well. Really fun experience.

Great staff, welcoming, quiet and elegant. I had the halibut with roasted pepper..didn't love the sauce. Fish was perfectly cooked.

The service is impeccable...almost as if the five people looking after your table only work for you. Finally the food is truly as you would expect in a Michelin starred restaurant. An elegant and quiet escape from the hustle and bustle of Fifth Avenue in New York. Caviar Russe is located in the 500 block of Madison Avenue behind the St. Regis. 
They specialize in caviar, champagne, Russian vodka and pate. If this is your thing, I highly recommend Caviar Russe. It’s not cheap, but nothing in NYC is. 

We were getting tired of the crush of shoppers and gawkers between Radio City Music Hall and Rockerfeller Center. So, we escaped a few blocks to Caviar Russe where we were treated like royalty. 

We tasted two ounces of Osetra and Servuga caviar, a bottle of Veuve Cliquot Rose NV, several iced vodkas and two glasses of Bordeaux. Total bill came in under $500. 

We loved the peaceful atmosphere and candlelight. The service was refined. The food exquisitely prepared.

My wife and I recently enjoyed an indulgent New Year’s Eve menu at Caviar Russe. First, the environment at Caviar Russe with gorgeous painted murals on the walls of the smallish main dining room with windows overlooking Madison Avenue is luxurious, refined, and beautiful. We were seated in one of the three plush crescent-shaped booths walking in on the right, which made for a comfortable setting to enjoy our evening. The decadence began with each of us getting 50 grams of Gold Osetra caviar along with a supplemental 125 grams of Sevruga caviar to share. The caviar was beautifully presented and served with crème fraiche, chives, potato slices, fresh made blini, toast points, and warm house made potato latkes. The caviar was exceptional. Following the caviar service, house made breads with three different butters (onion, caviar, and cranberry-walnut) were offered – the olive loaf with the different butters was delicious. Moving into the menu proper, we were then treated to a sensational tuna tartare topped with a generous portion of Osetra caviar in a mouthwatering soy-type sauce – just exquisite flavors. Next, a sphere of rich and delicious jelly encased foie gras topped with a nice mound of Burgundian black winter truffles resting on a bed of Sicilian pistachios served with freshly made toasted brioche – just wonderful. Then, a poached egg, topped with a nice portion of caviar in an absolutely sensational creamy parmesan sauce. Followed by tagliatelle pasta with an incredibly generous portion of freshly shaved white Alba winter truffles (the pasta was a tad undercooked, albeit the Alba truffles were exceptional). The final savory course was Dover sole presented and then deboned tableside, also topped with ample freshly shaved white Alba truffles personally shaved by the chef at the table. The dessert was a delicious chocolate ganache cake served with ice cream. Petit fours were also presented. We enjoyed the whole meal with free-flowing Dom Perignon blanc and then a glass of Dom Perignon rose poured to ring in the New Year. Certainly a pricey evening, but the high quality of the sumptuous food and the overall experience made it well worthwhile.

When an eight-course tasting menu turns into 11 courses (for the eight-course price), you know you have found an "I'll be back" restaurant.
And when each course is more than just one mouthful, the dining experience improves even more.
Fine dining in New York City usually comes at a price. But the prices here at Ukiyo in the East Village for the tasting menus in particular offer exceptional value for money - perhaps because the restaurant is so new, having been open (since late May) less than two months as I write this.
I'd definitely recommend a visit soon just in case prices rise or portions get smaller. Make sure you book: on my Tuesday visit 15 of the 18 seats were occupied.
As you would expect from a fine dining establishment, the dishes combine ingredients in unique ways, providing interesting textures as well as tastes - for example, a foie cocktail with pickled cherries, sakura blossoms and cherry meringue.
The chef and his team prepare the food in the open kitchen across from the dining counter.
Wait service is friendly and efficient.
Restaurant Ukiyo is next door to sister and Michelin-starred Jewel Bako Sushi. I wouldn't be surprised to see Ukiyo match that Michelin honour in the not-too-distant future.

Last night my wife thoroughly enjoyed the very friendly, completely delicious five course tasting menu. Actually there were more courses if you count the chef’s extras. Where to start? The potato leek cappuccino was a marvel, served in a big coffee cup with just enough foam. The menu says it all. The setting is intimate, seated facing the small open kitchen with the chef and two assistants working serenely, producing one fine dish after another. We were told at least one item on the menu changes each week. We look forward to our next evening a Ukiyo.

My husband and I enjoyed a marvelous dinner at Ukiyo. We ordered the 8 course tasting (there's a 5 course alternative) so that we could try more of the chef's creations and were very glad that we did since everything was beautifully presented and absolutely delicious. The chef is seriously talented but this is not a stuffy place by any means. You sit at the counter and the whole team is delightful, happy to answer questions and chat when they're not too busy. Service was equally personable and attentive. The room is beautiful in an elegant, serene Japanese style, and though the food is informed by Japanese cooking it draws from a mix of culinary styles. We both thought that the serving sizes were ample for a tasting menu. I had a couple of wines by the glass suggested by our server that were very good and paired well with the food. We felt that Ukiyo provides excellent value for the quality. One of the best places we've tried recently and we hope to return.

Ukiyo was formerly known as Degustation. We loved Degustation (aka disgusting hehe) and were so sad when we heard it was closing. It took us a while to realise this place reopened under a new name. We are sooooooo pleased and were farrrr from disappointed. 
As soon as you walk through the door, you know you’re in for a treat. From the dimly lit entrance you’re taken to you’re seat at the sushi bar. Everyone has the pleasure of watching the ‘artists’ (truly, that’s what they are) prepare you’re food. 
Since we couldn’t decide on a single item on the menu that we didn’t want to try, we went wild and ordered the 8 course tasting menu. Not only did we get our 8 courses, but a couple of little chefs treats too. One of the treats, an absolutely gorgeous crab dish, was one of my favourite bites of the night.
The thing I love most about this restaurant is the creativity that goes into the food. The combination of flavours and colours make each dish an experience. 
We washed this down with a lovely full bodied red. We usually go with the Tempranillo (similar wine list to Degustation), but instead we went with a Chilean blend that the server recommended. 
Which brings me to the service. We were so happy to see the friendly face of our fave waiter that had been there since we used to go to Degustation. He’s brilliant. Always good recommendations, always very attentive and super friendly! 
Pictures of the food to follow, with a strong recommendation to make sure you try out this little hidden gem!

I came here alone and had been hearing about the greatness that is David Chang and Momofuku Ko, so had to see for myself. I love the concept of being at a counter while watching the team prepare meals and interact with the diners, especially as for a solo diner. I was excited to start the meal and taste what was been deemed as ground-breaking. Honestly, the best thing for me was updating my iTunes playlist. About halfway through, I was so bored and uninspired, that I just wanted it to be over so I could go back to my hotel. Not to say that the food was bad, but there wasn't a single dish that blew me away (all I remember on my Uber ride back was that I couldn't remember anything that I ate). This style of prep and cuisine is a dime a dozen now at this level...I wish I had taken the same money, maybe even added a bit more and explored elsewhere. My time was wasted but the mystery is over and I can confidently say that I won't be back here again. More importantly, I don't recommend it at all.

Modern restaurant with a u-shaped counter concept so that you can see the cooking right in front of you. The food is good although nothing is particularly memorable.
I can away a little confused about the identity of the cuisine: it is definitely not Chinese or Japanese but it is not western either, quite "Pacific Rim" and includes a bit of everything. I generally love a Kaiseki concept but the Japanese gives the course more contrast between hot vs cold, raw vs cooked, fried vs steamed; at Ko every dish is about the same temperature and cooked in similar ways.
I enjoyed the meal but I do think there is room for improvement.

The Momofuku name is famous already but when you have no idea what you’ll eat until it shows up we knew we were in for a treat. This is a splurge but well worth it. More art than a meal but still delicious, filling and satisfying. Bucket list item checked off but I may repeat! Not an ounce of pretense from the staff as they graciously gave up their holiday

The staff were SO lovely that they could have turned a mediocre meal (not AT ALL the case here!) into a pleasure. The food was of course sensational and we left with that wonderful glowing sensation of total fulfillment. Well done guys and thanks so much!

We had dinner at Atera on our last visit to New York City and it was a truly outstanding experience.
First, we really enjoyed the dining room set-up which wraps around the kitchen as it gave us a prime view into the food preparation process. Service was also friendly and attentive and the soundtrack playing into the background curated by one of the Maitre D really helped in creating a fun yet reserved ambiance.
Food was excellent throughout with some nice innovative courses and some really flavorful dishes throughout the evening. We left feeling quite full and happy. We opted for the premium wine pairing which was quite frankly overpriced. If i go back i will select one or two bottles or opt for the regular pairing.
Overall great night at Atera!

Everything is perfect. The food is outstanding in its quality, originality, amazing combination of flavors, beautiful presentation and real food. Herbs are grown in their own garden in an Manhattan basement. Service is unbelievable, pricey, but a must go.

I celebrated my birthday Atera and was truly blown away by the food, the service, the vibe, the decor...everything. This was truly fun and inventive cuisine that doesn’t take itself too seriously. This is not a white tablecloth experience, and I mean that in the very best ways possible. The service was spectacular - unobtrusive yet still anticipating your needs. The servers are playful and smile, and you can tell everyone is happy to be there. Many of the courses are plated tableside, which adds a great dimension to the experience!
So, why did I dock it a fifth star? While almost all of the dishes were sensational (truly), the two meat courses - well, one poultry and one meat - were a) insufficient and b) the two least exciting courses of the night. The chicken course had good flavor and some fun nuance, but at the end of the day is still chicken; the veal course fell quite flat. It needed salt for sure, but it just lacked the wow factor. In a 15 course tasting menu, I could forgive 1 or 2 courses not be great, but these were the only non-fish/veg courses, so that made it super disappointing. Also, weirdly enough, they have no full bodied white wines by the glass, which is a huge miss and quite puzzling to me. 
I honestly give this place 4.5/5 instead of 4, but since Trip Advisor doesn’t allow half stars, I round down. 
It wasn’t perfect but was damn close, and I would RUN to go back again. I enjoyed the experience far more than the other Michelin-starred NYC tasting menus I’ve done!

Delicious little dishes carefully prepared and plated in front of you as you sit around a horseshoe counter with a few others. I thought the desserts were rather uninspiring which is rather sad as it is your last bite...was able to experience some flavors I had never experienced before.

For special occasion, including treating yourself, Atera offers extreme attention to each ingredient, its preparation, how it is presented (plating supreme) and staff interaction with you. They have obviously tasted everything before you have as all is delicious. We have low-carb no sugar restrictions and they figured out last moment changes just for us, you matter at Atera. We try to go every season and if you can, do so. A lot of the dishes were enhanced by white truffle this time and we happen to love it. The charming Rachael is irresistible. Everyone is extremely attentive. A special place (reserve early only 12 seats at this chef counter experience).

Atera is indeed a Michelin grade restaurant, no doubt about that. But the atmosphere left a lot to be desired. With the exception of the younger gentleman mostly in charge of the alcohol, the male crew exudes a level of PTSD that is beyond my comprehension. The chef seems to be going through some sort of intense existentialist trouble; he looked tense and all the cooks around him seemed afraid of doing a 'faux pas' or of not meeting his level of perfection. Something is not right with him. Don't get me wrong. The food was exquisite; the procession of amuse-bouches will leave an impression in your palate. But the atmosphere destroys what should be a memorable and delightful experience. We are not in a military academy, we are not in a cathedral, we are in a restaurant, trying to relax, attempting to take a break from our daily routine of struggles and ongoing challenges. Please do not put your guests through a stressful atmosphere; you will not lose or get a Michelin star by being uptight and communicating distress. SMILE. It is simple, easy and free; it will take you a long way to be charming with your customers. That is indeed what Atera needs from its chef and the males under his direction: CHARM. I will salute the exceptional service of the female servers, a true group of ladies of caliber who deserve recognition and promotion. They have a lot to teach to their male counterparts. The opening Lime cocktail, the oyster, the dumpling and the passionfruit mochi were the winners of the night. The restaurant's attitude was the loser.

Review text:
I’m bubbling over with excitement over the dinner we had at L’Atelier. 
Phenomenal experience from start to finish. 
Service was fantastic and they remembered that this is a special occasion dinner and treated us to some extras. 
We had $165 tasting menu (included caviar and lobster dishes). They matched wines perfectly to the meal. Presentation itself is absolutely picture perfect with whimsical twist. (“carrot cake“ looking like cartoon carrot)
This place is up to standard of L’Atelier chain.

Long ago we dined at the first L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon in NYC. It was a fun experience, but the current instantiation, open less than two years now, is much improved, and certainly worthy of its two Michelin stars. The wine list is generally pricey, but we were able to fund two wines, a white and a red, that were very impressive and not too expensive. Service was excellent. Overall, a wonderful experience.

Review titles: A bunch of very overpriced hype

Review text:
As expected: MAGNIFICENT ....
Cousy, small, warm, great and fine service, amazing servants and of course, best food

Stunningly Overhyped and Overrated at this point. This is my 3rd time here and I have to admit this first 2 were excellent. Alas, nothing stays the same and this recent visit was a shock to say the least. The portions are now at least 30% less in volume (Spicy Rigatoni) and the prices are at least 30% more, $36. This is a comparison from 2018/2019. The shrimp scampi are $24 per shrimp(yes, you’re reading that correctly). And they’re not even near colossal size. The linguine alle vongole was $42 and if I tried real hard I could probably get the entire entree on 1 fork. It also tasted as if someone dropped it in a salt bowl. Terrible. The apps (charcuterie) and the desserts were actually quite good and fairly reasonable. The service was also very good, which is why I gave 2 stars. But seriously, don’t waste your time anymore. It is way past it’s prime.

Our second time and likely last. Nothing bad, just that the charm of the first visit - ignited by how hard it was to obtain a reservation - kind of wore off this visit. We were again seated right at the front door in the row of two-seat tables so one of us (me, both times) had a view of a wall. Service is rushed. They slow down a bit if you order big or go for the $250+ wine list. When we opted for the more reasonable by-the-glass wine, we were pressed repeatedly for our order. Both times, we ordered the most famous items, the veal parm and the spicy vodka rigatoni. We skipped the meatballs this time as that was way too much, opting to split a Caesar. This go round, the rigatoni was very spicy - so much so that my wife couldn’t eat it. They kindly prepared her a half order of another pasta to replace it - which she loved. The veal parm was fine, but it’s $65 or more. Next trip we are going for an old-school family restaurant, but glad we got the opportunity to experience Carbone.

We recently went in for dinner to celebrate my birthday. We enjoyed every minute! We ordered the rigatoni and tortellini, which our waiter suggested a beautifully bodied Pinot Noir with it. The staff went above and beyond to accommodate my husbands request to put candles on a slice of chocolate cake. 
We can’t wait to return!

This place was delightful. We were a group of 8, including a small child. The waitstaff was attentive to multiple food allergies and/or restrictions and a “hangry” four-year old.
Favorites at our table included the garlic bread and mozzarella (house-made), the table-side prepared Caesar salad, the meatballs, and the pasta with spicy vodka sauce. I personally loved the market salad and Dover sole piccata, both with were milk free.
My co-diners had the carrot cake and tiramisu for dessert. Nothing was left on the plates. The restaurant also brought us three-color (red, green, and white) cookies. 
This is the perfect place for two-hour lunch or three-hour dinner.

When is a filleted grilled branzino worth $95? When is lasagna worth $100? When is veal parmesan worth $69? Or broccoli rabe at $18. NEVER. Carbone is all about the hype and “bragging rights” that you have dined at a top-rated NYC restaurant. Perhaps this is why the restaurant was packed with NYC Millennials. With 7 dishes shared among our party of 6, none were delectable, none deserved the high prices or any accolades. If you are really interested in quality food, do not dine here. The price gauging is beyond imagination – no wonder Carbone's does not advertise costs on their website. And don’t look towards the wait staff for help. We found our waiter to only suggest the highest cost dishes on the menu. And do you enjoy wine with your dinner? There are only a handful that are under $100. I truly believe the people who dine here and give it high marks have a limited palate and have not idea what fine food is all about. There are so many more worthy restaurants to pay your check at.

Everything about this experience was exquisite. The entrance is a little different, but very elegant and nice, our welcome was warm, friendly and efficient, the dining room is quite lovely, etc. We had the "standard" 4 course prix fixe menu, so between the two of us had 8 different dishes. All were excellent. It is hard to pick what was best...I particularly liked the squab consommé with port and foie gras...but everything we ate was lovely. 
Aside from the food, the service was a standout. It was attentive but not fawning, warm and friendly but not too familiar, efficient but not rushed, etc. 
I was not interested in buying a really expensive wine, so to do something different, I consulted with the sommelier and picked a 37 year old Gigondas (still expensive, at least by my standards, but not over the top) on the theory that while it was most probably well past its prime, it might be something different and perhaps surprising. The sommelier was going to decant it, but after a taste he advised that he didn't think that it would bear up well to decanting. I think he was right, and the wine started out very nicely and got a lot better with time in the glass. The point of telling about this is simply that the sommelier was very helpful and perfectly willing to spend whatever time it took to find the right wine. 
In the course of our meal our main server was very attentive, but we were also served by several others, and were visited by the manager (I think that's who he was), who was checking up to see how our meal was going...impressive in that he not only knew what we had eaten, but what we were having for the courses that were coming up. At the end of the meal we were visited by Daniel Boulud himself, who very graciously stopped by our table for a very nice 5 minute chat. 
I don't think that we got any special treatment...we were just ordinary patrons, and as far as I can tell, everyone got the same gracious treatment and superb service. It was the mark of a really good restaurant.
Of course, Daniel is very expensive, but that was no surprise. And if you want a quick meal, I don't think this is the place. We were in no rush, and I suspect we could have hurried things up if we wanted, but our meal took something like 2 1/2 hours. And why not prolong such a lovely experience!

Make no mistake, this is a very expensive Omakase. Right at the reservation website, you’re instantly charged $300. And at this price point, it must be perfect.
The ambiance is quite fancy once you can find the place. It’s quite hidden so there is someone outside to greet you in case you can’t find it. What’s confusing is a few stores down, there is another Omakase in plain view which I am thinking of trying. The storefront there definitely looks better. Here, there is no storefront and you have to be guided to a labyrinth which takes you to the restaurant. Basically, this used to be someone’s apartment.
The waiting lounge is nice and quite fancy. They won’t let you forget you are in a fancy place with everyone dressed formally in business suits and the bar is the type you see in James Bond movies. The dinner did not start in time and we had to wait about 10 minutes before we are escorted to the main dining room.
The main dining room can seat 9 ppl but depending on the night, they will take some chairs away and on this night, it was less than capacity which means more elbow room. The chairs are quite plush and comfy. Possibly the most comfy Omakase seats I ever sat on. The decor is a nice blend of traditional mixed with contemporary. As with most Omakases, there is never a window around and so it’s the usual stuffiness. Make no mistake, the counter is quite expensive and made of quality wood and the old-styled lantern light covers add to the atmosphere. The pop songs playing in the background may seem out of place but it looks like they’re trying to target the younger crowd vs the banker type as this night shows.
There is only one chef with his assistants in the background. The chef introduced himself before the meal to everyone and is quite friendly, probably the most friendly chef I ever met. As he chats with everyone, it’s easy to overlook he is serving so many ppl all by himself when at most Omakases, 3 to 4 is the max for a chef. Talking and preparing is second nature to him and he never missed a beat in his preparation.
All the niceties are here. Warm towel, finger wipe, napkin, and prompt service.
I found the cooked dishes were quite good and better than the sushi portion of the meal. The sushi was of good quality but small and somewhat generic. There were no star dish during this meal and it was all quite forgettable to me.
I also decided on some very expensive liquor but they do not even pour in front of me. When it’s more than a 100 a sip, they should pour in front of me. A very big miss here.
In all, it’s not a $300+ meal unless you enjoy being pampered but I look for a balance of ambiance, food, and service and they only succeed in the ambiance. There are many exceptional Omakases in the city that cost only $200 including tip and tax and some even less and they all have a star dish but here, all you get is an expensive bill with nothing much to cheer about.

I don’t know who to blame: Tock or the staff at Noda for their mistake. I paid a 1000 dollar meal in Tock in advance for a special occasion and they wanted to charge the bill again at Noda at the end of the meal, when we already drank their sake pairing… They don’t have to be a genius to know that one of the couple already paid the bill in advance. 
 Who cares about the sushi, their ambiance, their decor when they charge double? I used Tock before and it was success. I guess it was the Noda team that saw us drunk and they though: “This is the moment to charge them again”. After we uncover their scam, I told the waiter that I already paid in Tock, and he answered, “Oh really?” Run away from Nada!

Noda is special! They earned a Michelin star in a vey short time after opening and I could tell why. The restaurant doesn't have a sign on the street - just a door with a number. When you enter the small intimate bar area you can tell you are in for a fantastic experience. The restaurant seats only 8 and only serves omakase. Chef is personable, fun and engaging. Definitely splurge and do the Sake pairing. We should have shared one because it was a LOT of sake. Every detail to this gem was covered. The food, service and experience were all amazing. HIGHLY recommend.

Noda is curated to be an experience from beginning to end, but the focus remains on Tsunoda-san's skills and an excellent selection of ingredients. While the space may be more warmly decorated than a traditional high-end Edomae sushi restaurant, it retains the same tranquility due to the intimate design as well as a minimalist approach the keeps the focus on the fish rather than the garnish.

The meal was at least as good as any omakase I've had around the world, including at chef's former home at Sushi Iwa. Selection varies daily, but the Hokkaido uni chawanmushi with caviar was a delight to start, and the botan ebi is a personal favorite that is too infrequently seen. Every course was delicious.

The pre-dinner signature cocktails were unique and creative, and the Japanese whisky selection is extensive with knowledgeable staff to match (although perhaps not the easiest on the budget). Similarly, the sake list is wide-ranging. My only regret is not having gone with a bottle -- while the sake pairing provides a good tour of styles that match the meal, it did not seem like a good value compared to the bottle offerings.

Definitely one of the top sushi options in NYC.

Review text:
3 of us had dinner on March 2. The food was good - what there was of it. The portions were surprisingly small. A main serving of duck breast and foie gras had about a one inch square portion of duck, and a slightly smaller one of foie gras. A pasta main was a bowl half filled with pasta and barely noticeable amount of ragu - and that was $36.
The special of Venison was very good. 
The room is pretty and the service was pleasant, but considering the prices and the portion sizes, I would not go back.

With a three piece jazz band in the corner and lively atmosphere, you won’t necessarily expect a classic seven course prix fixe but you should get it. While you can get the menu a la carte, the prix fixe is the best way to try many of the delicious pasta and seafood on the menu. Service is excellent and on par with any other Michelin Star restaurant. They also have great cocktails as well as a couple of non alcoholic cocktails- a trend I’m very happy about. At the end of the meal they give you a little loaf from the sister bakery to take home - another trend I’m happy about.

In some ways, sadly, Benno is a mixed bag. If Ambiance, Service, Food and Price are the four key evaluation categories, Benno scores high on most.
The menu is limited and non-mainstream, and the food is exquisite. In every way top-notch, and up to the most rarified competitors in New York. The portions are small, but the food is well imagined, high-quality, exquisitely produced and plated, and delicious.
The service is practiced, trained, formal but friendly, intelligent and delivered by a team. If only they had more to do. 
Prices are high – very high, but in a different environment you would expect it. 
Ambiance is the problem, and one wishes given the earnestness and skill of the staff that there was a way to overcome it.
Nothing wrong with the address. So many old buildings are being converted or reconverted into hotels, this being one. Jonathan Benno evidently oversees the street-front bakery, the more casual restaurant plus the formal restaurant.
The formal restaurant is in the back, a large, double height room with a skylight atrium. It may have been created from what was a backyard and converted into an inside room. It is not warm.
On a Tuesday night the room was considerably less than half full. The combination of décor, volume, location and graceless access through the other parts of the hotel to the back combine to create an energy/ambiance void, which never went away, notwithstanding the high level of service and exceptional level of the food. This is a problem.

I sat at the bar for my solo dinner. The meal started with an amuse bousche, which was tasty, followed by a couple Parker House rolls with onion-laced butter, which were quite good. My first course was the risotto with black truffle. The amount of truffle shaved on the risotto was quite generous.
I got the duck entree. The foie gras was delicious although I would have liked the interior to be a bit warmer. The duck sausage was very good. The duck was good but a bit tough. The beans and root vegetables were very tasty.
Both of these courses were a bit small and I was still hungry. I decided to get their cheese course. They only have one choice for cheese. It was OK but it wasn't one I was thrilled by. I would have liked more choices. It was also a fairly hard cheese, which couldn't be spread on the crackers. Like the appetizer and entree, the cheese course was rather small. I ate the crackers with the small amount of jam provided. It wasn't nearly enough for all three crackers so I ate what remained by themselves. They were rather hard and difficult to chew.
My server, the bartender, was very knowledgeable about the food and quite attentive. The atmosphere at the bar was OK. I'd prefer a little higher light levels but I could read the menu. The noise level was low for a bar. They play music, which you could barely identify since the volume was so low.

This is a non pretentious, fun place that carries amazing food. Yes, the pasta portions are small, they tell you not to consider pasta a main course. So I went for two pasta dishes! Carnaroli risotto and chestnut agnolotti. Both came with abundant black truffle. I am picky when it comes to truffle, but they held up to my standards. Their dishes are rich, almost a mixture of Italian and French cuisine. They brought a couple extra little plates that also were very good. 
Tip, wine and several cocktails after, we spent about $200 each. Worth it. 
I loved that the place didn’t pretend to be a starred restaurant but that the food actually met the standards. I liked it more than frenchette and other “hot” restaurants in nyc 2020
Beautiful premises. Excellent service and creative, delicious food. No detail was spared. We look forward to returning soon. This place deserves a second star.

Review titles: The best meal of our two month visit. Deserves a second star.

Review text: Located in the art deco Evelyn Hotel this place is dripping with chic and cool. We had dinner on a recent girl's trip and this place was beyond anything I could have expected. When we were seated in this beautiful room, each of received a stool for our pursues so they would not have to sit on the floor or hung on a chair - seems so simple yet civilized, but set the tone for the entire place. The manager greeted us and we discussed Italy and where in Italy he was from, everyone who served us was so engaging. The four of us had the 8 course tasting menu with truffles and everything was presented and tasted just awesome. It had a little of everything from the menu and we requested a dish with sea urchin since all but one of us had never had it before, we figured this was the place that would make it well (and it was). Risotto, pasta, skate, lamb loin, sirloin, cheeses, finished with four different desserts which we passed around the table, plus more littles of this and that, we truly did get a taste it seemed of everything. The service was excellent and all our dishes were explained, and came at a regular pace. Our dinner took about 2.5 hours and it was enjoyable every minute and bite. Probably one of the best meals I have ever eaten. With the company of great friends, it will be a cherished memory forever.

3 of us had dinner on March 2.  The food was good - what there was of it.  The portions were surprisingly small.  A main serving of duck breast and foie gras had about a one inch square portion of duck, and a slightly smaller...More

Review titles: Very Deserving of its Michelin Star
Extremely expensive for an imperfect meal

Review text: If you ever wondered how a restaurant with zero decor and poor service but decent sushi can earn a star Michelin, now is your chance. I never questioned the sanctity of the Michelin rating system until I visited this place. Avoid at all costs. The only aspect that is Michelin-esque is the high price. Disgusting decor like a tired diner and consistently poor service (only one server) would make you cry if it wasn’t so funny as is the rating.

Review titles: AVOID like your life depended on it

Review text: The food was exquisite, each course got the taste buds going!!! The Chef & staff explained every course, even were it came from. The service was great and the atmosphere was good. Great to go back again.

From the start to the end every bite offered personally by chef and prepared in front of you is absolutely maximum of freshness and choices for one dinner . For example I have never tested such incredible tuna....
The sushi & sashimi in this place is the best you could ever get . Ultimate pleasure with incredible selection of Japanese fresh see food. It is naturally quite expensive, but which good sushi place isn’t !

It's really a small Omakase Sushi place. There are tables, but to get the real experience you have to sit at the counter and have Chef Inoue serve his Omakase. 
It's not cheap, and I've never sat at the tables, so I don't know how that goes. Never a problem at the counter, perfectly paced and exquisitely crafted. I don't really want to write a review because I don't want it to get crowded... it's that kind of worst-kept secret-kind of place.

Review titles: Eating like in the best sushi place in Japan

Review text: My husband took me to this restaurant for my birthday on a Sunday night. We sat at the counter and it was like dining with a private sushi chef. The food was amazing, very inventive and extremely fresh and tasty. I loved everything we were served. They also had a nice bottle of wine as well as sake and beer on offer. The chef was extremely personable as was the waiter. The only reason for the 4 star and not 5 was the fact that the decor and lighting really left something to be desired. Otherwise it was a 5 star experience and worthy of its Michelin Star.
I'm not sure how they've kept their Michelin star. The sushi is fine, but does not justify the high price. The service was also really bad. Disappointing, not worth it.

Best sushi I’ve ever had. Perfect evening ! Surprised to find sushi in Harlem. 
Sushi were well seasoned, perfect mix between soy sauce, wasabi and sometime lime. You won’t find fishes or shells directly coming from Japan. 
Chef explained to you every sushi. When he saw I couldn’t finish it, instead of stopping serving, he kept going and put it in a box. 
Spent a great evening!

I am usually loathe to write negative reviews, as even restaurants with below average food make an effort to please. Sushi Inoue, however, is not to be included in this category.
$275 pp omakase advertised as 7 appetizers plus soup, sushi and dessert. Only half of the listed appetizers on the menu were offered- the rest were substituted with cheap choices. On top of that, they only served six appetizers, rather than the listed seven. The substitutes consisted of a canned tomato soup with overboiled noodles, a sweet corn soup with a piece of frozen shrimp(still frozen and obviously tasteless) and a fried sea eel tempura which was also tasteless.
Unit tasting was the best of the lot, but still mediocre at best, compared to other high end sushi restaurants.
Coming to the sushi, the only above average piece was the mid fatty tuna. One piece was octopus, which is never offered in high end omakase restaurants. The rest of the nigiri was completely forgettable. Fatty tuna hand roll consisted of two blocks of mid fatty tuna and one block of regular tuna-why mix the two?
Dessert was a complete embarrassment- half a soggy wafer wrapped around green tea ice cream, which was likely purchased as one piece at a Japanese deli for $1.
Finally, the restaurant adds an automatic 20% tip!
There are so many lower or equally priced omakase restaurants in NYC which based on Inoue’s 1 star deserve 4 or more(if such a thing existed...)
This place will not be around much longer and is trying to milk whoever shows up until it closes down..

Review titles: How can this place have a Michelin star?

The sushi & sashimi in this place...More

Maybe my worst experience ever in a sushi bar. Because of this place I’m never eating again in a high end sushi in New York. Avoid this place at all costs. It was a scam. The hostess didn’t receive my coat, the sushi was good but nothing special. The problem is that it is hyper expensive for what they offer. Their Michelin star may help them to survive, but in reality it is not worth it. They just have two sakes, the house sake, 75 dollars, mediocre. and the premium sake. A Michelin star sushi and they don’t have Sake menu? With different options…? Pfffft. Thanks Sushi Inoue for spoiling the sushi scene and for saving me thousand of dollars that I will not spend eating again in this kind of places.

Just writing this makes my mouth water at the memory of the wonderful tastes. Great and friendly service. The chef is very friendly and explains the food. I have been there several times in the last year and enjoyed.

Very private and beautiful clean design sushi bar layout for one of the best kaiseki tasting menus in the city. 
Food is top notch with high end ingredients (some flown in directly from Japan), exquisitely prepared and meticulously plated. It is worth the splurge to escape Manhattan and be transported away to a zen like state for 2.5 hours.
