It was the highlight of this second trip to NY city.
Everything was...More

Review titles: Good restaurant but not for a Michellin Star

Review text:
We went there for my 36 year old birthday. On monday, you can bring your own bottle of wine, so we jumped on the occasion to try this 1 michelin star restaurant. 
It was the highlight of this second trip to NY city.
Everything was good and amazing. Our server was really sympathic and helpful. 
Every dish were perfect and we took one more at the end just because.
We brought a 30$ us cabernet that we drink at home regularly, and they never judge us on our choice. They made us really comfortable. It was important for us because it's not everyday that we could afford a dinner like this and we all know that some restaurant make you feel that you're out of the league as you enter their restaurant. It wasnt the case for Le Bâtard.

We have been to Batard and chose the 3 course menu.Both the appetizers and main courses were tasty and well executed. However, they were qiute classic and conservative with the flavours and textures. Compared to other Michellin star restaurants, I felt a bit disapointed, since I expect some surprise or new flavours / textures and I didn't get that. 
We didn't like the flavours in the souffle we asked for desert, For our taste it was too sweet and spicy and did not enjoy the icecream that came with it either. 
At the end, it felt pricey for what we have eaten (300USD bill wiht one glass of wine each) for a three course menu that didn't impress. The room, atmosphere is also quite more casual that what we are used, with quite some noise in the room and very limited space between tables

We tried the 3-course prix fixe menu and the choices were excellent. Plenty of food. We were there on a Monday when there is no corkage fee, so we brought our own wine. Service was gracious, location in Tribeca great and atmosphere was quiet enough for good conversation.

Review titles: Excellent French Food in a Sleek Location

Review text:
The restaurant is lovely, the service polished, the oysters with avocado and the branzino were superb, and a little card waiting on the table acknowledged my birthday. It was a Monday, and we brought our own wine, which was kept cold and served graciously.Two things keep me from giving five stars. First, the chocolate cake dessert was heavy and not up to the quality of the other courses, and a candle was placed in my husband's dessert (I didn't order dessert) to acknowledge my birthday. Second, my husband had four courses, and I had two, but the bill read as three courses each, which came to a higher total. We told the waiter, but he said there was no difference.
But these are minor complaints. We will definitely return to the restaurant.

a long but worthwhile trip from the UES to Batard is always rewarded by a warm welcoming adult establishment frequented by a devoted coterie of upscale guests. no flip flops or tank tops here - Monday is no-fee corkage, so having a substantial cellar we generally choose this venue. cocktails are excellent: rightfully billed as one of the best Old Fashions in NYC. choose the duck and you are in for a taste treat.
chef Marcus Glocker and staff will make your experience worth the trip

We went on a Monday night which offers free corkage! Otherwise corkage is $50. Wonderful dinner. We started out with foie gras and octupus for our appetizers and both were excellent. The foie had a nice sear to it, just awesome! For our entrees we had the snapper and duck breast. The snapper was delicious and a nice size portion. It was from New Zealand and I hadn’t had snapper from NZ before. Loved it! The duck was delicious as well and had a small portion of foie with it. Service was stellar. Very attentive and friendly. Definitely will return.

I have been going here for years and sending people here for years. The food is amazing !!! We hosted 16 people for a client dinner. They are all foodies and were absolutely raving about their meals! Not one unhappy person. Adam and chef went out of their way to take care of our group. It was one of my top restaurant meals in the past year. Ambience is romantic and chic it’s a don’t miss in nyc!

If you want an excellent meal, Batard is the place to go. It's a comfortable restaurant with modern design. Tables are spaced nicely with plenty of room. The food is wonderful, plated well with the most amazing sauces. The carrot cake is on the top of the "best" list. The staff is friendly and helpful. West Broadway south of Canal St. is a little bit out of the way, but worth the trip. It is expensive.
We went on a Monday evening and not only was the food amazing but Monday night is BYOB.  We had the duck and rabbit sausage.  It was great

This particular restaurant is in an unassuming location in Tribeca. When we pulled up, we barely noticed it on our left. I recently visited this restaurant with customers for a work conference we were attending in the area. I was very impressed by the duck, black bass, sweet potato tortellini, Amish chicken and the chocolate dessert. However, I thought that the soufflé would be a lot better than it actually was. I tasted like an omelette to me with all of the egg whites on the inside. The service was good and the ambience is pretty nice as well.

Unfortunately, quite far off from the Michelin star experience we expected. Firstly, when ordering restaurant is rather inflexible with allergies (primarily seafood allergies as there are prawns in majority of dishes). We had the Butcher’s Feast plus some extras and the meat itself was okay - definitely wasn’t the nicest we’ve had but not horrific. The service was decent they came over and cooked the food for you although when different servers are rotating it sometimes led to the meat being overcooked. The worst part - we both left feeling unwell stuck on the toilet and given the queue for the restrooms at the restaurant I don’t think we were the only ones. Very unhappy with this experience as we expected a nice meal to finish off our holiday in NY.

Great restaurant overall. 
Attentive and well educated staff, great feel/ambiance and most importantly great food.

We are from Italy and a cold wine is unacceptabl.Really bad attitudes, the sommelier was really annoying cause I took a sip of wine, I mean I’m 19 years old a sip of wine should be okay but not for her, she told all the waiters that I couldn’t drink, and literally everybody kept on steering at us it became kind of weird and awkward that we just wanted to leave this restaurant. Also a guy from my age knows more then a sommelier that doesn’t know that the wine has to be warm and not cold. The meat it’s okay nothing special. Least but not last the sitting place are really uncomfortable my ass was in pain after sitting for one hour inside the place, the ambience is sad and cold. You can spend 200$ in better places

We visited Cote together with some friends and to say I was excited before the visit would be an understatement. We arrived and started with a couple of drinks in the bar, they were all well presented and tasty, I also appreciated the bartenders willingness to accommodate changes to the cocktails. 
Once seated we opted for the Butcher's feast and also added the A5 Wagyu. All in all, the food was amazing. Depending on your palet you will enjoy some meats more than others obviously but the flavors were there and it was all cooked to perfection by our waitress. We also had the scallops which were on the specials and those were fantastic! 
We rounded of the evening with a cocktail in the bar downstairs which we would have completely missed if it wasn't for our waitress recommending it when she overheard our conversation about where to go for a last drink. 
We will be back on our next visit to NYC for sure!

A great experience for anyone who loves Korean food. The restaurant is very trendy and the welcome was warm.
The food was really tasty with decent portions; we went for the steak tartare and Korean bacon to start, followed by the Butcher's Feast. Wine prices were OK, especially for New York.
Overall, it wasn’t your traditional fine-dining experience. I did feel like we were a little rushed. One of the servers was also the most miserable man alive! Quite difficult when it's such an intimate service, with him cooking the meat in total silence as you sit awkwardly.

During the pandemic, we had to hastily rearrange our wedding. We couldn't have our family or friends at the wedding, but we decided that we could look for amazing food. Enter Cote - they sent us the best meal that we've had this year, and portion enough that we'll be eating it all weekend. They even included a lovely note and present. Amazing. If only I could give 6 stars....

Really good place with the best service and great food. Booking is kind of difficult and I can imagine why. It is so popular. I really enjoyed the experience. Get 100% attention all the time from the waiters. Top notch
We didn't have a reservation, for 2 of us, but they fit us in. If you've never had Korean BBQ this place is a fun and great place to start. They are very attentive and the food is delicious.

During the pandemic, we had to hastily rearrange our wedding. We couldn't have our family or friends at the wedding, but we decided that we could look for amazing food. Enter Cote - they sent us the best meal that we've had this year, and...More

We visited Cote for my husband's birthday and it was overall an enjoyable experience. We made sure to make reservations and since it's a party of 2, the only options were 5:30pm and 10pm (I believe). Book early because it fills up quickly. We went for 5:30 so we could go for a walk afterwards. 
We were running a bit late and they had a grace period of 15 mins which we just made. We were seated at a large booth which was very spacious. Our server came by shortly to welcome us to Cote asked if it was our first time there (and it was). We weren't super hungry so we wanted to make sure we didn't get large portions. Even after stating this, the server still recommended we get some appetizers which we did. We ended up get the shrimp app with the Butcher's Feast as our main. Along with that, there were many side dishes, rice, soup etc that came with the meal. The appetizer wasn't needed. The cooking itself was done by the server and she would go around from table to table and cook for all the customers. She was friendly enough but didn't seem like she really wanted to be there (just my opinion). She would explain the cut of the meat and cook in front of us. We were given a bunch of sides before the cooking started and about 1/2 way through the Butcher Feast, a bunch more sides came out. Everything was good and authentic, however we were pretty stuffed at this point and wasn't really enjoying the meal as much as we would like. 
Definitely come hungry and perhaps skip ordering any additional apps since the sides they provide are plentiful! We were given complimentary ice cream which was very yummy but they did not provide any additional complimentary dessert for my husband's birthday (which was fine since we were stuffed).
The ambiance, the service, and the swift service were all amazing! The butchers feast allows you to try all the different cuts but the portions could be better.

Review titles: Good food and service but not special
Daniel Humm’s Eleven Madison Park is just oh-hum.

Review text: I skipped this restaurant last year and went to Per Se instead. This time it was inevitable that I had to stop by and went back to Per Se for the 2nd time at a different night (see my review). Service here was ok. I felt that I was rushed out of the restaurant. It took about 1.5hrs to finish my dinner which was the shortest I’ve ever dined at any fine dining restaurant, much less at a 3 Michelin starred restaurant. I was very disappointed ... I wanted to savor every bite with ease. My palate hasn’t fully enjoyed the last dish when another followed in minutes. I also had to keep asking for hot water and sliced of lemons. My waiter did NOT do a good job of checking back to see if I needed anything. Very unprofessional I must say! I’m a Michelin Star enthusiasts and been to several 3 Michelin stars all over the world completing the eight 3 Michelin stars in the Bay Area (see my profile and reviews). The highlight of my visit here was seeing the kitchen where the magic all occurred. I can’t think of any dish that made an impression. Even the caviar with cheesecake wasn’t impressive. I mainly ate the caviar; the cheesecake was unnecessary. Had dinner at Aquavit two nights before and their caviar was so good with a beautiful food presentation (see my pix/review).

Beautiful space, friendly and efficient service with thorough knowledge of every dish. Very creative dishes but the price level is higher that other three star restaurants I have visited in Europe. I dislike the prepayment system with no cancelation which I have not seen in any of the two dozen three star restaurants I have visited.

Our recent dinner has become an annual tradition celebrating a birthday and wedding anniversary. The eight-course tasting wine-pairing is an extravagant splurge and festive occasion. The young, energetic staff work efficiently to provide service that is satisfying and memorable. My only complaint, and it sounds like a quibbling one, is that the meal, while varied, tasty, and luxurious is also minimalistic. In terms of value ($295) and expectations for world-class cuisine, in terms of the top 50 restaurants on Earth, I find Eleven Madison Park somewhat lacking in pizzazz and thrills. My meal had some tender lobster, a bit of black caviar, a few oysters, some trout, and a nice petite sliver of duck, but après tout, I asked, is that it? The dessert underwhelmed, and as in the past, there was no chocolate petit fours but only some excuses muttered unconvincingly. The more modest wine-pairing at $175 per person additional had some nice vineyards and complimented well but lacked depth. Compared with Marisawa of Tokyo or Pierre Gagnard’s Arpège of Paris, Eleven Madison Park’s Chef David Humm is simply not in the same league.

My husband and I have had the privilege to dine at a fair amount of Michelin starred restaurants, and dinner at Eleven Madison Park was absolutely the best experience we have had. The ambiance was incredible, such a delightful space, but really and truly what made EMP unforgettable were the service/people and the food. EMP's staff were both genuinely welcoming and attentive. They made us feel like part of the family while still providing the best service. Madison was amazing throughout the night, and ushered us from entree to entree seamlessly. Little details throughout the night showed her attention to detail; for example during conversation about her hometown we disclosed that our dog was from the same city, and at the end, she had a take home bin of treats for our pup. That was so thoughtful and really speaks to the remarkable service. Brady (the sommelier) was equally as incredible. He helped my husband pick the right bottle of wine for his palate and also made great recommendations for cocktails for me. He was kind enough to show us the cellar, which is incredible. Lisa took us to be back of the kitchen where one of the pastry chefs prepared a quick little dessert bite for us during the kitchen tour. It was a true pleasure seeing the "well oiled machine" that is the Staff at EMP working so seamlessly together while somehow managing to make us feel extra special. 
In regards to the food, every plate was perfectly balanced. The portions were generous, compared to other restaurants. The platings were elegant and not over done, the taste of the food was amazing. From start to finish it was a treat. Brandy and pretzels at the end of the night was a delightful surprise. It is obvious that a lot of thought has gone into the dining experience. Thank you EMP for an incredible night. Usually we try to experience new restaurants, but our night at EMP was so enjoyable, we will be sure to be back

From the very early moment till getting the bill, we can realize the reason behind the tree Michelin stars granted to this restaurant : the service provided by gentle waiters is flawless. They are skilled to be around without bothering you. 
I have tried the tasting menu . It was quite good. I should say Daniel and Le Bernardin are still the best ones in my own New Yorker ranking, but 11 Madson Park is certainly as good as them.
I liked much the pragmatic sommelier : he realized I had got scared with the New Yorker prices of my favorite Bordeaux´s ( way more expensive than the price in Paris). Then, he suggested a Napa´s "honest" alternative to replace it. It worked ! 
The reservation was made two months in advance . I have got surprised with the requirement of paying at the reservation moment . That´s unusual !
I do recommend the experience.

We had really high expectations given the ratings and accolades. Maybe we were expecting too much. I still give this place a 5 stars as the meal was phenomenal and the service was great. This restaurant setting is average and almost a little crowded for a Michelin 3. This would not be a place for personal special occasions but great for corporate events or dinners.

With unbelievably high expectations as supposedly the worlds best restaurant, this did not live up to the hype. The chefs genuinely missed on a few key courses which you cannot do at these prices. I will not return and highly recommend no one else wastes their time until this place gets restored to its old charm and menu

Review titles: One of the best choices in the world..

Review text:
Best dining experience of my life ever! Every part including service, food, wine pairing, and atmosphere are beyond expectation. I asked to meet Cedric the Wine Director and actually he was off on that day but, eventually came back to have a chat with me. Max the Head Sommelier also showed us the wine cellar and kitchen! What a privilege!! Server Alessandro was brilliant too. Really we did not expect these at all. To create a WOW experience and to delight guests, no one else can do better than the Eleven Madison Park. 
超棒的用餐體驗, 無論是服務, 菜色, 餐酒搭配和氣氛, 都無可挑剔. 餐廳的服務非常到位且溫暖, 甚至會極盡所能的滿足客人的特殊需求, 例如我在訂位時附註想跟葡萄酒總監Cedric 見面, 當晚他不在, 但是牠竟然敢回來跟我碰面! 這家餐廳對於製造客人驚喜, 無人能出其右.

This is definitely the best meal I have had in New York City so far. I loved every dish on the tasting menu - from the poached lobster, to the soy with truffles, and the pear sorbet. Not only were the ingredients fresh, the cooking was done to perfection. 
Worthy of mention is the stewed veal which came with some roasted potatoes and bacon - its presentation was like flower with layers of petals and tasted delicious (too bad that I didn’t take any picture).

They also have an extensive wine list with a decent selection of wines and cocktails - something not to be missed.

Service was good. Attentive staff but not intrusive. Despite being a fine dining restaurant, we didn’t feel suffocatingly stiff - in fact we quite enjoyed our chilled long lunch there (some 2.5 hours). Would definitely go back when we next visit NYC.

Our recent dinner has become an annual tradition celebrating a birthday and wedding anniversary. The eight-course tasting wine-pairing is an extravagant splurge and festive occasion. The young, energetic staff work efficiently to provide service that is satisfying and memorable. My only complaint, and it sounds...More

Every aspect of our experience lived up to expectations. Room is spacious and comfortable, the service and servers (of which there are many) was friendly and efficient and the pace was great. Even though we were there for almost 4 hours, we never felt neglected or wondered when the next dish was coming. It was just a nice, relaxed pace. The food was also delicious. Every course was beautiful on the plate and also tasted great. We had requested to visit the kitchen and that was fun as well. Overall a great afternoon. Wonderful choice for a special occasion.

A subliminal experience from beginning to end. Incomparable culinary creations, impeccable service, classy ambience...and very high prices to match all this. We were seated in the lounge while waiting for our table, in very nice high chairs, and offered house made aquavit. The dinner that followed was nothing short of spectacular. Every dish was a culinary adventure, and the service was impeccable.
We had the seasonal menu, added a cheese selection, Bird's Nest dessert. And the horseradish aquavit, wine, glögg, and coffee as for beverages.
It was not cheap at $446 total, but worth it still.
I and my wife are actually Swedish but now live in America. I can guarantee that almost nobody in Sweden eats this extravagantly, but there are Swedish elements in this restaurant's cuisine.
We had an amazing experience at Aquavit. We took the eight course dinner. Each plate was exquisite and full of flavors. It is on the pricier side, but worth it for a special occasion!

Best two Michelin Star restaurant I have ever visited. We were started with a heavenly cured salmon ribbon over a camomile gelée. The main dishes were the cod and the beef, both very creative, delicious and beautiful. The chocolate and créeme brûlée desserts were works of art. We are returning next week

Quiet, elegant environment with entertaining menu choices for three, five, or eight course, prix fixe dinners. Trout and herring starters excellent and wonderfully presented. Duck and pork entrees also superbly cooked and presented. Fine selection of wines by the glass and aquavits. Service subtle, unobtrusively attentive and responsive to exotic dietary demands. For those who want to spend $150 pp and up, this is a joy.

I was excited dining at Aquavit with such high expectations. That was bad on my part as I ended up being disappointed. It all started with an amazing array of size bite goodies that were all so good. Then came down to the bigger dishes and it wasn’t up to par. In the end, the wagyu beef with the black truffle supplement made up for it. It was one of the best wagyu I’ve ever had despite of not being from Japan, but rather from Colorado, USA. Wagyu wasn’t as marbled, but was perfect and wasn’t too rich. It was perfectly prepared to perfection. A gentleman by the name of Nieko waited on me and he was very attentive. He’s very passionate about his job and he takes pride in it. Service was excellent! Overall, it was pleasant, but wished some of the dishes were better.

Review text: Awesome Scandinavian food. Fixed price menus are wonderful but VERY expensive. I recommend reserving in the “bar” and ordering ala carte. Herring, duck, meatballs all terrific. Service is excellent.
We had a good experience at Aquavit. We enjoyed the scandinavian twist of the menu. Food was tasty, but salty for our standards. Resonable wine list.

Every year during Christmas, Restaurant Aquavit is serving a spectacular Christmas smorgasbord. I was one of the lucky visitors just before Christmas, however, I did not have to help myself to the delicacies, since one sample after another was brought to my table. 
First gravlax (marinated salmon) and three different herrings were served. The gravlax melted in my mouth and the the three different herrings were delicious. Naturally I drank a danish beer and started lightly downing an aquavit with Islandic design. 
After tossing a few cubes of cheese from the north of Sweden into my mouth, I realized this was just the beginning. 
More food consisting of homemade prince sausages, Swedish meatballs and barbecued ribs landed on the table. 
More beer and aquavit arrived as well. 
I stuffed myself and loved every second. 
Before I reached the finish line I enjoyed a “kladdkaka” and a miniature princess cake for dessert. 
To visit the newly renovated two star Aquavit restaurant is a must. 
The restaurant is the same, but much better.

Coming from Scandinavia, Xmas dinners are very different and it was great to get many of 30-50 different dishes we normal get during our many xmas lunches during the month of December. I must say that I completely over ate and couldn't really try the deserts, but they are usually also not an important part of the xmas lunch. 
As the chef is Swedish, it missed some of the Danish curses, but overall I enjoyed it and the quality was excellent. The reason for 4 stars is that my wife was less impressed and really needed a few salad options (although they are not really part of the original xmas lunch). 

The glogg was very tasteful.

Uncle Boon's does not accept reservations. They also lie about wait times. I got there before the rest of my party at around 6, and there was no wait but they can't seat you until your whole party is there. Then, my friend got there at 6:30 to put her name down, and they quoted her a half hour wait. Not knowing that we already put our names down, our other friend got there at 6:40 and they quoted her an hour and a half wait. They're supposed to text when the table it ready, so we go to a bar nearby. It's 7:15 and we still haven't received a text, so we decide to go to the restaurant to check it out. They tell us that it's still going to be another half hour. We didn't end up getting seated until 8. So my suggestion would be to go right before 6, and that's the quickest way to get a table. 
Seating situation aside, the food is pretty great. It's authentic Thai food, so you won't find Pad Thais or Pad See Ews here. There were so many things we wanted to try but we narrowed it down to a few to share:
Plaa Hoi Shenn (raw chilled sea scallops with basil seeds, lemongrass, basil blossom, and passionfruit nam prik) - the actual scallops were good, but I wasn't a huge fan of the passionfruit nam prik
Hoi Tak (green curry snails with crispy garlic & herbs) - these were SO good. Our waitress suggested we order a side of naan to soak up the sauce and it was the best idea
Kao Pat Puu (crab fried rice with egg, cilantro, and lime) - this was my favorite dish of the night. I loved the huge chunks of crab, and the green chili sauce it was served with
Khao Soi (golden curry with egg noodles, chicken leg, pickled mustard greens, and fresh turmeric) - a pretty solid Khao Soi. I really liked the broth. It was a bit too much pickled mustard greens though
Massaman Neuh (boneless beef ribs with massaman curry, potato, red onion, peanut, and green peppercorn) - not my favorite. Not sure if it was because of the texture of the beef or the peanuts (or maybe both) but I probably would not order this one again
For drinks, I tried the Bolan cocktail (jasmine bourbon, lemongrass, angostura bitters). I didn't really taste the jasmine or the lemongrass. The bitters was over-powering, so it just tasted like an Old Fashioned.
I don't know if I'd want to wait another 1.5 hours but I definitely want to try some of their other dishes. Next time, I'll just make sure to come right before the dinner rush.

Uncle Boons is a unique food experience. The plates are family style ~ so to be shared by all in your group. The food is fresh and the menu is tight. This place is packed so be ready to wait a LONG time for a table ( we waited 2 hours for a 4 top on a Thursday night ) and the seating is almost European with tables so close together you can not get out without asking your neighbor for some space. Overall it was worth the wait and the ingredients and service were top level. Dress code is casual, not good for kids, no handicap access and no large groups. Thanks Uncle B ~ tasty food night!
Really cool atmosphere with great food. This was our best restaurant experience in NYC. The food was very good authentic Thai cuisine. I would definitely recommend.

I have been to this restaurant twice and both times I leave with the desire of coming back as soon as possible. This is by far the best Thai restaurant I have been to outside of Thailand. The freshness and flavors that explode in your mouth are an unforgettable culinary experience. All the dishes I have tried are delicious. Go there with the mentality to be adventurous, I for example don’t eat lamb and I tried their lamb salad and it was amazing! Their escargot appetizer makes your taste buds go to heaven! Their mango salad which is their version of the traditional green papaya salad is so full of flavor is just spectacular. Everything I have tried is just excellent. A must go to and certainly one that will keep me coming back for years to come.

Review titles: Best Thai restaurant I have been to

Review text: Delicious Asian plates to enjoy with  a couple of friends or a large group. I went there with 6 friends. As most dishes are for sharing, it was perfect for our group.

Review titles: Food is really good but be prepared to wait

Review text:
A few New York friends recommended this place so I was expecting amazing things however it was massively disappointing. The one thing that rated high for me was the atmosphere. There is no doubt this place is bustling with people willing to wait over an hour for a table, however after having grown up in Australia and New Zealand, fresh produce is something of a rarity in New York.
The baby octopus was overcooked and powdery, and the charred bits consumed any other flavour. The rice that accompanied the duck was so drenched in duck liver it made the main duck too rich to eat. The ribs were fried and covered in salt when they really should have been slow cooked to let the really flavour melt in your mouth. Overall, things like charcoal, sugar, fat took over where the flavours of the core ingredients should have shone through. Freshness is key in Asian food and the dishes felt like anything but fresh...it was all overdone.
You can get Asian food in Australia and New Zealand that’s a quarter of the price and much better quality.

I've eaten twice at Uncle Boon's (UB) and twice at Uncle Boon's Sister (UBS) over a three-year period of time. Every single dish I've had at each restaurant was spectacular, unquestionably the best Thai food I've ever eaten. Sometimes different dishes at Thai restaurants have a somewhat similar taste. Not so at UB and UBS. Every dish has a totally unique and completely delicious flavor. On my most recent trip to UBS, a few days ago, I had roti with pumpkin curry, curried lamb pastry and Thai basil stir fry. Each dish was a knockout. UB and UBS both have a hipster vibe BUT, unlike some other restaurants with that vibe, the service is friendly and warm. Go! Your taste buds will love you.

I'm sorry to see that not everyone has a great experience here. 
Ours was amazing and we'll worth the price. 
We started with the snails, lamb salad and chicken salad. All very good with the lamb a d chicken standouts for me. 
Large plates were the chicken and egg noodles curry, beef short rib curry and the whole fish. The fish and chicken. We're to die for. 
Overall, the service was absolutely excellent and the atmosphere a bit loud but the food made the experience for us.

Quite disappointed. First of all, it’s a fire trap. The guests couldn’t get out if there was a tragedy. There would be a committee established to determine the cause. No need, I know what the cause would be. Really surprised the city does nothing.

As for the food the baby octopus and the marrow presentation were quite good, the rest rather mediocre. They also have a terrible policy of bringing food out when it’s ready. Haphazard to say the least, and quite annoying to get the crab fried rice after all plates have been served. And it’s expensive with no justification.

I definitely wouldn’t go again or recommend it.
Recommended! Tasty food, good staff, we enjoyed our evening there! Specil thanks to waiters, so professional!

The location is a bit out of the way in a nondescript part of the city however once you walk through their doors you find yourself in golden lit dining rooms with the comfortable buzz of conversations from the happy diners. The tone is casual elegant so no sneaks expected but no jackets required, a nice comfortable balance. 
There is a nice selection of offerings to cover all food preferences and they are also accommodating to special dietary requests. My friend and I came in planning to do a sampling from the menu and our waiter, Travis, brought to our attention that a dinner option was a four course prix fixe that would provide us with all our planned choices and dessert as well, a great option if you are going for the full menu options. We started with oysters and leeks with hazelnuts. The oysters were clean and fresh tasting with a nice hint of the sea, the leeks lightly cooked in a very mild sauce with hazelnuts was a pleasant bite. We then moved on to the foie gras in a light but delicious jus, and the toasted bread that came with the dish was well appreciated to sop up every drop of the sauce. The foie gras was melt in your mouth wonderful. We also had the faux snails which were actually a layering of a mussel, turnip, and topped with sea urchin served in a snail dish. Again a little bread will serve you well to mop up the remaining sauce in the snail cuppings . For the main courses we tried the halibut over dakon , the fish was tender and the white sauce enhanced but didnt over power the taste, the mildly tart dakon was a nice counterpoint to the sweet fish. The prime filet was tender and it's accompanying side of oxtail under thinly sliced potatoes was a richly tasting meat lovers treat. I'd like to mention that portions are fairly generous and one could easily order less than we did and still have a very satisfying experience. Desserts were elegantly made and almost too beautiful to eat...almost but we enjoyed our Tarte Tatin, Chocolat Coucou, and a version of a classic Baked Alaskan. 
Wine and beer options are good and cover all price points and staff is knowledgeable to offer recommendations to fit your tastes and budget.
While this is not an inexpensive restaurant, it is a good value restaurant when you consider the quality of the food, the excellent service, comfortable surroundings and that you will be enjoying your meal for a couple of hours at a nice leisurely pace. An enjoyable experience from beginning to end. A special thanks to our waiter Travis who was informative and helpful throughout our meal and truly made us feel welcome, it was a pleasure to have met you.

We celebrated our 12th anniversary at Le Coucou. I think they deserve much better recognition and accolades. Plain and simple. Their service, food and wine pairing are all head and shoulder above rest of their contemporaries!!

This is a very French place in terms of the menu and the wine list. We had excellent food save for one fish dish which was fairly plain and monotone (in taste and in fact in appearance too). A good buzzy feel of lots of people enjoying their meals but perfectly possible to talk and hear each other without any strain.

This Restaurant obtained a Michelin Star and ever since then it was very difficult to get a reservation. Luckily, our daughter booked it several weeks ago. The interior was designed beautifully by Roman and Williams, with heaps of chandeliers. Linen covered tables with candles.
We had the four course meal and between us tried the Celeri Remoulade au Crabe (excellent), the Foie Gras Artichaut (very good), the Dover sole and the pigeon (outstanding).
Their house cocktail is the English Milk Punch, which we enjoyed and then managed to find just about affordable wines from their ginormous wine list: we had Boulay La Cote Sancerre and a Clos Du Marquis, as well as a small bottle Marengo Muscat to go with the Foie Gras. 
The service was good and friendly (with a hint of attitude by some) and we had a most enjoyable evening.

the iconic library inside the hotel restaurant was a new treat for this New Yorker.  I'll be back for breakfast and dinner.

Brunch at The Nomad to kick off my best friend’s birthday weekend in NYC was only fitting. I mean, you can’t go wrong with a place awarded a Michelin star and opened by the same team behind Eleven Madison Park, or can you?
I was getting old New York glam vibe with the red velvet fabric from the curtains and seats in the main dining area which was where our reserved table was. There’s seating in the courtyard as well which I thought had a whimsical and casual feel to it. 
Gin-based cocktail to start please! With sweet and tarty notes to wake up my tastebuds, Nod to Nothing prepared me for my meal. For food, first came the Brussels Sprouts fried with cayenne and brown sugar served alongside buttermilk for dipping. I’ve never seen this preparation before and I’m not exaggerating, this has been the best I’ve had yet. A little thrown off, I expected the Chicken Sandwich to be fried. On the menu it says “Chicken Sandwich - brioche, black truffles and foie gras”. Sounds like a winner, yes? Maybe if it was fried. The Carbonara was the one dish I was looking forward to but a shame how underwhelming it was. 
On the bright side, it was only the beginning of a fun-filled celebratory weekend and I don’t have to worry about getting a reservation and spending an arm and a leg at Eleven Madison Park anymore.

We enjoyed the roast chicken three ways immensely. The vibe here is dark, hip, very cool. Seating was comfortable and the service was absolutely perfect. In addition to the chicken, we recommend the tuna tartare and the "milk & honey" dessert was absolutely lovely. It was packed, but somehow not too loud, something I find rare these days.

Elegant decor,impeccable service and wonderful menu is a place to have an extravagant dinner. We had the Nomad chicken and it was prepared in 3 different ways,we were not satisfied with our wine but they gave us 2 complementary appetizers.

Simple and Slique – The Nomad Restaurant
If ever you want to have a fine dining experience, but you don’t want to pay the high price of fine dining, do some research and see if your restaurant of choice offers a breakfast service. This way you can have the experience, and not only pay a lower price, but you also have the advantage of dressing very casual (leggings and sneakers). Upon entering the nomad hotel, the dark tapestries give you a sense of mystery, and I immediately think “Prohibition Elegance”. It’s rather dark when you enter the hotel, but it opens to the dining room which is beautifully lit by the natural light of the open ceiling. My server Raul was very attentive, when he walked me to my table, he immediately took my coat and checked it for me. My menu was already placed on my table, so my glass was filled with water and coffee immediately followed. I am a coffee snob, and the coffee here is exceptional. I ordered the omelet with hen of the woods mushrooms which came with multigrain toast and salad greens. The meal was tasty, but the omelet a bit salty. It’s presented with coarse sea salt on top of the omelet, but in my experience coarse sea salt is very salty, and I believe it should only be served on the side. Raul, and another young lady (whose name I did not get) were very attentive to my needs, and when I was ready to leave, I had a rare experience where Raul held my coat up and put it on for me.  It is indeed the little things that I pay close attention to. I enjoyed the meal, but the service took it over the top. I give the meal an 8 and the service a 10… Awesome!

Review titles: Over-rated; shouldn’t be one star Michelin
The New Standard for NYC Sushi

Review text: This place was highly recommended. No doubt the quality of the fish is very good although I have seen better in other places. I was a bit disappointed with the standards. Example the rice feel of the Nigiri sushi few times. Something which should not happen after high end quality sushi restaurant. The decor and atmosphere is a traditional Japanese sushi counter. Service was very friendly and efficient. One issue which how is that surprised me was when I asked for the bill. I was presented with a bill, I gave my credit card, The waitress took the credit card and swapped it through the machine and brought the bill back to me. I asked there do I need to sign it and she said yes. So I signed the bill picked up my stuff and started to leave. Half way on the stairs I was surprised with the waitress chasing me and almost shouting that the tip is not included in the bill. I have no issue with paying a tip but they should have explained that when they presented the bill rather than choosing a customer on the stairs. I found this to be unprofessional.

This is a very good sushi restaurant - don’t get me wrong. But it is just over-rated.
The fish is as fresh and as good as they come, but my criticism comes from the lack of creativity and differentiation for a one star restaurant. I can very much claim to have tried some of the best sushi restaurants around the world, and Michelin starred sushi restaurants always have one thing in common: giving you some pieces that can only be experienced at that restaurant. This is either via the sourcing of fish (arising from superb knowledge of seasons and where, globally, to acquire the fish from which source and via connections), the way the piece is put together (flavoring), or both.
As you can see from my photos, there is pretty much zero surprise from beginning to end. Every piece of fish/dish I can recognize and taste I can recall. The preparation is exactly how it is - plain vanilla with soy sauce.
If you are looking for a first class, run of the mill experience but with the best fish of its class, then you should come here. My view is that the chef is simply not experienced enough (he’s too young). He couldn’t have had learnt either the deep culinary skills or having the network/relationships for fish sourcing to provide a world class experience. 
And the fact that the restaurant has 2 seatings, 6 and 8:30, really bothers me. It means that commercial opportunity is prioritized over experience. The preparation of fish is “altogether” when each piece is served, and without a team (solo chef) it is clearly very taxing on the chef. The focus was therefore execution rather than thought and careful preparation.

The price is reasonable at $250 for omakase, but then again comparatively the price-to-value isn’t that great. My suggestion is for the restaurant to go back to the basics first. Really earn that star rather than trying to maximize the commercial opportunity at the same time.

Review titles: First time and will definitely be one of our favorites in NYC

Review text:
I visited as a solo travelling diner on a Saturday night and could not fault the personal service including sympathetic understanding of my request to have a break between appetiser and entrée - to be prepared on my signal. 
The octopus appetiser was a delight - crispy on the outside and very moist inside, not at all rubbery, with an intriguing crispy pork mince and foam, both of which provided depth and texture. The halibut with Asian curry flavours was likewise incredibly moist and not overpowered by the subtle sauce (neither too thick or too conconutty).
Both dishes interesting but highly accessible and satisfying. 
The restaurant had a nice intimate atmosphere and felt very personal and stylish but unpretentious.
I'll be back if I have an opportunity.

Located on East 5th Street between Avenues A & B in the East Village / Alphabet City district of downtown, NYC, Tuome is a relative newcomer to the NYC food scene… but with very impressive and weighty credentials. Billed as a “contemporary American restaurant with Asian influences” it meets that label pretty damn well.
In a stylishly decorated, large space, with exposed brick walls interspersed with decorative panels, plaster & ceramic wall tile, mirrors, empty frames masquerading as artwork, potted flowers, bare wood floors and tables, funky lighting, etc… this space is at the same time exciting and functionally done. The noise level is a bit high, though, because of this.
The menu is also a bit sparse… and while the prices are above average, the portions are ridiculously small ~ way below average. 
We had 2 glasses of rose wine ($28) and a plate of chicken liver ($14) to start, and then asked for the wagyu beef ($38) and snow crab pasta ($33) as our mains. Initially, we were planning to order another salad and share the snow crab, and asked the waiter if this was a large enough serving for us to share, and he assured us it was ~ stating that it had “a full crab shredded over the pasta.” Sounded great, but well, look at my photos. We could barely see the crab, and definitely didn’t see the squash.. it must have been juiced ! The beef I ordered instead of sharing the pasta was also a pathetically tiny serving (photos …again !!) It was gone even before I could decide if it was good.. another reason to stay away from these “small plates” rip-off wonders.
Won’t be back, thank you. If you think your food is so great, please provide enough for someone to get to taste it before its gone, instead of just thinking of your profit line !!

I went to TUOME with my wife and Child for celebrate the birthday of my oldest daughter I was very impressive with the menú and quality of the food, without be an extremely expensive restaurant because carry a Michelin Star it was excellent in all ways

Tonight’s visit to Tuome was nothing short of exceptional. We live in the neighborhood and had often thought of visiting this restaurant but were often confused by the Michelin star which was overshadowed by the opinions of other self critics here on trip advisor which said it was way overpriced and overrated.
Tonight, despite the reviews, we decided to check it out for ourselves. I must repeat emphatically that is was nothing less than exceptional! We started the evening with a beautiful little potato and ricotta dish that was sent out as a gift from the chef. It was light and lovely but that was only the beginning. We ordered some very nice cocktails. I ordered he dragon sangria and it was a nice way to start off the evening. We ordered the octopus, the deviled eggs and the chicken liver mousse and although all of them were superb we thought the foam brown butter sauce on the octopus deserved special mention. It was so rich and had a such a great mouth feel , but it also had a wonderful taste, which is often absent in a foam sauce. As for the entrees, we shared the pig out which was a crispy pork belly with 3 different sauces on the plate, and a side portion of peanut noodles and although the pork was delicious the real standout was the garnish of arugula salad with lycees and candied walnuts. We also tried the halibut with a gorgeous light curry cream sauce that was superb as well. Everyone at the table loved the crab noodles which were very light in taste but very delicious, but the winner for me was the side dish of rice. It was sweet and pudding like and went so well with the curry and the pork! Last, but not least we had the roasted carrots with a smoky sauce and they showed just how versatile and skilled the chef was to do so much with simple ingredients like carrots. We were so stuffed we literally couldn’t eat all of our food. It was all so rich and had so many different sauces and flavors. We were completely overwhelmed by this unassuming little restaurant that leaves behind the pretentiousness but delivers on the flavor. We couldn’t leave without trying their dessert and we all shared an order of beignets with vanilla ice cream and red bean paste with a squeeze bottle of caramel sauce on the side. It was the best ice cream sandwich ever. We walked home amazed by this completely unexpected and delightful experience. The service was outstanding, the food was delicious and rich and satisfying and i wondered to myself how it could be that anyone could complain about it. My only advice is, if you are reading this review, if you really like a massive steak hanging off your plate with no sauce, you are definitely in the wrong place; however, if you enjoy watching the imagination of a perfectionist chef run wild, this might be the place for you. After dinner we debated would we go to Marea or Le CouCou or Aqyavit overTuome and we all decided we wouldn’t miss this for the world!!! Go see for yourself, its an unforgettable experience.
Wow food was phenomenal delicious very tasty Compliment to the chef very good finish with the perfect dessert definitely need to come back

Tuome is a Contemporary American cooking with Asian influence located in a cozy little space on 5th Street near Avenue B. Came here on a Tuesday night and the restaurant was busy, VERY busy! We had 8:30pm reservation for the bar and yet were not seated till a little past 9pm.
The service is solid and friendly, which helps, and the crowd here was slightly older than average for the East Village. It does look like a popular date spot
The star of the show here is the “Pig Out” (for two), which consists of little squares of crispy pork belly with sides of peanut noodles. 
The Pork belly squares are delicious but I honestly didn’t care for the peanut noodle, it was overly sweet for my taste almost like straight out peanut butter. Don’t miss the snow crab, it was really yummy!
We ordered almost the whole menu LOL!! Definitely a #pigout night
Appetizer – 
SHRIMP TOAST - wasabi aioli, watercress, chives
CHICKEN LIVER - mousse, maple, milk bread. I’ve been thinking and telling friends about this dish since we tried it. Chicken liver mousse on a toast with the sweet maple syrup, sea salt, and pumpkin seeds, it’s just awesome. A must!

Main – 

PIG OUT (FOR TWO) - berkshire pork, spicy peanut noodle, condiments. For $49, you get 10 blocks of crispy pork belly, and two bowls of al dente peanut noodles. That’s a lot. A pretty rich choice for date night, but come with a few friends and get one for the table.

SNOW CRAB - noodle, squash, dashi butter

Dessert - 

BERRY - coconut pudding, berries, almond

BEIGNET - goat's milk caramel, ice cream, citro

Review titles: TUOME a 1 Star Michelin Restaurant in East Village NY

Review text:
We booked this restaurant as we wanted to experience a Michelin Star restaurant in New York. The food was stunning, we opted for the full story with wine tasting pairings. The staff were attentive, friendly and very knowledgeable about the dishes and the wines to match them. 
The atmosphere was chilled and we didn’t feel out of place as you can at times in high end restaurants. The only observation having dined in Michelin restaurants in the UK is that the price tag is a little hefty, this is the only thing that would deter us from coming back.

Hi John, 
We're very sorry to hear that your experience at The Musket Room didn't live up to your expectations. 
I understand you may have dined with us on a slower night when the majority of our guests were seated near the bar. I see how that can make the front of the restaurant feel empty. 
As far as the offering, our short story tasting menu is described "about six courses," which is six composed dishes plus bread service and petit fours. Thank you for the feedback regarding the beef; we have passed this on to Chef. 
While we certainly do not think of International wines are ordinary, we want to make sure all guests are happy with this offering. We stand by our 3 oz pours as this is quite customary industry wide but I will look at the producers featured on the evening of your dinner and see where there may be room for improvement. 
I want to extend our sincere apologies if you had to request menus or have the check dropped before you were ready. 
We appreciate your comprehensive feedback and will use it to improve. 
If you should choose to dine with us again in the future, please let me know and I will make sure to send a glass of something special to make up for this past experience. 
Thank you and best regards,
Jennifer Vitagliano and TMR team

This place has a Michelin star, which denotes fine food and a comparable environment, but the decor and ambiance really only warrant "Michelin recommended" and the service is downright unsatisfactory.
When we arrived, we found all the customers (about twelve) huddled in the rear of the restaurant, which is not a welcoming sight. We were shown to our table, then ignored for more than five minutes whilst the waiters (all male) talked among themselves and/or played with their ipads behind a low separating wall. I eventually had to demand menus.
The meal itself (a seven dish tasting menu called Short Story) was disappointing. The chef is obviously talented, judging by six of the teeny dishes, but the big item, New Zealand beef, was chewy and tasteless. 
What really turned me off, however, was the International Wine Pairing, priced at $60, and consisting of 5 very ordinary wines (some without even a domain name) with an average retail price, by my calculation, of $25, which makes the restaurant's cost per 3 oz. glass at about $1. To be subjected to a lengthy eulogy about the wonders of what was basically up-market plonk was almost more than I could bear.
The check, which was presented before we had even finished, was calculated based on a minimum service charge of 20%. The total for 2 people was an outrageous $400 and I left hungry.

This was like a home run derby, each dish hit it out of the park farther and farther. The most creative restaurant we have visited recently. We had the vegetarian and short tasting menus . The spreads with the bread were unique.

I'm definitely happy I went. The dishes were pretty unique. The presentation was great. Was the taste amazing? Not really - Would I go again? probably not - but it's definitely worth a visit for the creative tasting menu

Hi Lou,
We are sorry you didn't have a great experience. If you can reach out to me via email, we would love to discuss and have you in again. You can reach me at events@musketroom.com. 
Thank you

The tone was set when on arrival we ordered a glass of bubbly only for it to be served in a wine glass. When asked if we could have a champagne glass, we were told that they do not have any - is this Michelin Star service??? We opted for the Short Story Tasting Menu. Presentation was excellent, but the taste was somewhat lacking. Each dish seemed to be rushed to our table with no time to savour the flavours. Pricing of the wine was beyond extreme - a bottle of Cloudy Bay Sauv Blanc 2018 Marlborough NZ for USD$134.00! What an absolute joke (conversion from AUD to USD $23.00 to buy in a bottle shop in OZ). Staff presentation was lacking, very casual. For the price that we payed (for 2 adults) inclusive of drinks was just over USD $420.00. For this price we would expect to be well fed with exceptional service but unfortunately this was not the case. Thankful that it was a one off only, we would definitely not return.

Myself and my partner chose The Musket room as we were in New York for a week and wanted to dine at some of the best restaurants the city has to offer and I can safely say this is not one of them. We had such high hopes after reading the previous trip advisors and seeing they had a star but we were simply disappointed. The food was mediocre and there were varying wait times between each dish. The first few were served within minutes of each other and then the last few took much, much longer. We weren’t once asked if we wanted another drink, our glasses sat empty for 20 minutes until we could get someone’s attention to order another. We also weren’t asked how we were enjoying the food which as several courses we didn’t finish, I feel it was quite obvious we were not happy. The venison dish in particular was under seasoned, tasteless and luke warm. I just feel when you are charging $165 a head you simply cannot provide such poor service. We left feeling deflated and not being given the opportunity to rectify the issues also added to our disappointment. Finishing on a positive note, the cocktails were fantastic in taste and presentation.

Definitely has to be one of the top three meals I’ve ever had for total experience. While there were a couple of near misses, some of the food was top of the top. The beef croquette was one of the best bites imaginable. The king crab and pea purée was spring in a bowl. 

We were there for 4 hours and felt like royalty. Vanessa was perfection. She made sure we were living every minute. Our bartender great. All the rest of the staff was amazing. They even all signed a birthday card for my wife. 

It was a wonderful night.

Review titles: Good food but not Michelin star service

Review text:
We were very excited to dine here but things didn't go well early on. My husband and I brought a good friend from out of town as we all enjoy fine dining and tasting menus. Both my friend and I were celebrating our birthdays, so were up for something special. Both the food and the service disappointed. Early on we were told no substitutions, even for food we could not eat. This resulted in us skipping between 2-4 dishes apiece but still paying for them. At one point the meat served our guest was so tough she could barely cut through it. The sommelier poured uneven glasses to each of us with the wine pairing even though we were all paying the same and our waiter seemed to disappear part way thorough the meal.

With so many excellent restaurants in NYC, will not be visiting again.

Visiting NYC from the UK, booked The Musket Room for my partner’s birthday. Chose the short taster menu.
Food enjoyable - my favourite dish being the pavlova with passion fruit. 
Slightly alarming was the scallop dish arriving when I was still eating my sourdough from the earlier dish. The waiter just moved my plate to one side & put the scallops down (I felt kitchen timings had probably been off in this case due to the menu supposedly being a “story”).
Having eaten at several 1 Michelin star restaurants in the UK I know what to expect & sadly the vibe was not for me. 
Felt more like a fast food restaurant - waiters rushing about, didn’t support a relaxed dining experience. Music was loud, restaurant very noisy so struggled to have conversations. 
LOTS of tables crammed in - again, my experience of 1 Michelin star restaurants is that you have a unique dining experience, sadly this wasn’t it. Whilst I am all for a relaxed dress code, there were people sat with hoodies & hats on eating. 
I have no problem with this when I am in my local chain restaurant but not when I’m paying over $100 per person for a meal.
Suggest a trip over to the UK to see how 1 Michelin Star is really done.

Tempura Matsui is certainly a fine, Michelin starred restaurant. Tempura lovers will appreciate the exquisite texture of the fried paste, an extremely thin, tasty and light coating, covering ultra fresh ingredients, BUT, all this comes at an abnormally high price. 
There are 3 fixed price menus and I would advise going for the cheapest. The price difference, important, is not justified by what you get extra, noticeably a sashimi appetizer, fresh but not exceptional, that will cost you a preposterous amount of money.
Sitting at the bar (recommended) you can watch the two cooks at work, as they skilfully craft the tempuras right under your eyes.
Yet, the atmosphere is icy, as too often in high-end Japanese places. Obviously, the chefs are not there for exchanging smiles and the lady “Maitre d’Hotel” watching over each of your movements is more intimidating than entertaining.
Good Japanese restaurants in NY are now more expensive than their counterparts in Tokyo and the “de luxe” omakase, popularized by the master Jiro Ono, has inspired his New-Yorker alter-egos who run the same formula, only for a much higher price, although none of them can compare with the Ginza magnificent chef..
Tempura Matsui is a good example of this unfortunate trend. U I had even better tempura in Japan, particularly in Nara old town (meaning being transported in a Kurosawa movie) for a much lower price...
I was told that lunch is a more affordable treat.

This gem is almost like being in Japan. They specialize in tempura which was expertly crafted and served. My only disappointment was that they do not serve the tempura individually, course by course, like in Japan. Other than that, everything was authentic and delicious and the service refined.

You could have the real Japanese style Tempura here.
I recommend the counter table so you can enjoy the live show of cooking tempura right in front of you.
Before they serve tempura, you could have some wonderful authentic Japanese style appetizers
Price is a bit expensive but it worth it.

San is the reason to come here! Even with the holiday mess this place is serene and stylish. Book early! Go mid afternoon before the chefs take lunch. Relax and appreciate your quality ingredients and preparation. Splurge for the lobster tempura. High Point: service, methodical service, serving trays, sauces, and ingredients Low Point: we had to leave! Unique Point: New York's only and best tempura bar! Toto toilets!

Unless you're in Japan, this place will make the truest substitute. I'm just grateful an establishment like this even exists to fill the void from mediocre and down right bad tempuras all over NY and the rest of the US. 
Pricey but worth the top end ingredients and service.

Review titles: Comparable to best tempura restaurants in Japan

Review text:
After having lived in Tokyo for many years, I felt nothing could compare as far as authentic Japanese Tempura. Well, I learned otherwise. Tempura Matsui proved that! Everything about the rest. Was perfect!! The
Ambiance and decor were first rate. The food and service was impeccable. It is small and very intimate. Delightful dinning experience! The ladies room was a sight to behold! The heated toilet seat left a lasting impression!

After loving tempura in Tokyo (Tempura Ginya) we have been looking to find a similar place in the US ever since. We found it! Great choice if you are looking for a quality light Japanese tempura (not like the deeply fried heavy “crap” we all know). They serve not only tempura but also their traditional style tofu and other dishes that taste just like in Japan.

This is a wonderful tempura experience, especially sitting at the bar. Each course was excellent and the service is very friendly and polished. The combination of tastes and textures are a treat for the palate. And although fried, everything is light and fully flavorful -- from the crispy prawn heads to the maitake mushroom, Japanese onion and pumpkin. The chef, Chikano-san is delightful as is Sanchan-san, the Maitre d'.

Big fan of Tempura Matsui. Have to point out the excellent service this restaurant provides, from the initial check-in of the coats, to the attentiveness of the wait staff, to the constant refilling of drinks, and the explanations of each dish and how to best consume them. The quality of the ingredients were top notch, leading to top notch tempura. The side dishes were also impressive.

Dinner for one was $165 with no alcohol. Service was very good, food was good but the price/value point is difficult to justify. I was the only guest besides another table where a child was misbehaving, removing the lid of the rock salt container and licking the content. I did not want to see that. No one stopped him.

Review titles: Best tempura this side of the planet
