My Husband and I came here for dinner in the middle of October. We had a reservation but arrived early and ended up eating at the bar. The bar tender was detailed when describing the menu offerings and had extensive knowledge of the wine list. I have a wheat allergy that she helped me navigate with ease. Everything that we tried was interesting, thoughtful and flavorful. It's a very small restaurant, but I liked the coziness of it. I would definitely come expecting to drop some $$$ and order multiple plates to share. I had two glasses of wine and my husband had a few beers. We split two plates as appetizers and then each ordered our own plate for the main meal. They have a handful of rotating wines available by the glass and then a biblical sized wine list for bottles available.

Perfect bread - tick!
Friendly service - for sure!
Tip top tunes - you bet!
Delicious dishes - certifiably!
Intimate setting - ain’t no doubt about it!
Rare orange wines - indeed!
Do we recommend this restaurant? YASSSS!

For brunch the food and price here are great.  $35 for three courses set menu.  Service is good.  The beef bourguignon, salad, and dessert were all very good.  Dinner is not a set menu, and I would be eager to return.
They have a delicious orange wine and their food has an amazing flavour  combination, The tangerines as an appetizer is a must.

8 of us enjoyed a fantastic custom designed menu featuring some of the most fresh and innovative flavours. We had a wannabe foodie in our group, but the staff were more than up to the questioning on both fine and wine. Great location and atmosphere. Would recommend to anyone visiting Brooklyn and looking to pack in a whole spectrum of culinary delights in one sitting.......be prepared to have deep pockets mind. Fantastic.

Review titles: Perfect from start to finish...Increasingly less well kept secret of a restaurant

Review text:
Very interesting and special combinations of materials and flavors. 
Be prepared for very small portions though.
very casual place. small tables. young people in general. 
worth try it.

Great wine choices, lovely food, ambiance and wonderfully knowledgeable and friendly staff. This was the first night of our first trip to New York, and was our wedding anniversary, and we realised almost to the day 3 years previously we had watched LCD Soundsystem which was our absolute highlight of a very rainy Glastonbury 2016. So it seemed fitting that we went to James Murphy's restaurant and noticed him sitting across from us. We'd definitely recommend for the food, drink and environment.

This place is incredibly deserving of the Michelin star it was awarded this year. The worst part - you can't make a dent in the wine list. The best part - if you go with 4 people, you can get the chance to try a good portion of the daily menu. We had an intriguing white to start and a fantastic burgundy with the entrees. 
Running through the food..grain of salt on what to order because I don't love cheese and I handled ordering:
Oysters - really good, came with like a fresh red pepper/mix/light vinegar ready to go, some of the best oysters I've had.
Marinated Mussels - these were fantastic with an onion mix on top. Great mix of flavors + presentation.
Mauntauk Sea Scallops - raw with daikon on top, really good, we almost ordered a second.
Tuna - interesting tuna presentation as one long raw piece, in a great peppery/oil sauce (interesting as in good).
Skate Wing - fried, which I should have anticipated, done perfectly and the pineapple slaw on top was delicious.
Gnocchi- Not a cheese or gnocchi person, but these were perfectly delicate and the chives added a nice crunch to the sauce
Chicken - The sweet potato mash was great, presentation is cool, skin of the chicken was fantastic...was a top tier, very moist chicken...perfectly well done, but compared to everything else wasn't a highlight.
Ribeye - was delicious, most expensive thing on menu but perfect for sharing, good sauce on it, and a really good flavor from the dry-aging.

No dessert for us. Great meal.

What a night we had here! I live in the UK and read about this place in a wine subscription so I made a point to come here. The wine list is extremely impressive (although there is more old world than new world I believe). My girlfriend is dairy and gluten intolerant and this was handled extremely well! The bartender/sommelier gave some great recommendations for wines by the bottle we ended up having a New York State Pinot Noir which was very unique. 
The place has a great buzz to it without being too loud we were able to speak comfortably to each other. 
I wish I could come more often 
Thanks for a great night that we will remember for a long time!

Visited from London and unfortunately left it too late to secure a booking here which was high on my list of restaurants to visit. Luckily we secured two seats at the bar by walk-in on a Tuesday night. I had very high hopes but I have to say that it even surpassed them. The food, wine and service were all absolutely fantastic. It's fairly pricey but if you're into your food and wine it's 100% worth it.

Review titles: One of my top 5 meals ever!!

Review text:
This Michelin restaurant was hard to find, as it is located amongst lots of fast food places, and arriving there by car, the driver didn’t know in which direction to point us, and out of five people working inside the mall (yes, this is also a mall) 0% knew what we were asking about. Of course, we did find it at last, hence the review.
The dishes were well composed and good, however missing that little extra in the seasoning. I also found it quite disturbing when our waiter went overboard in trying to sell us the Caviar extras, as I expect this to be handled in a much more subtle way at a restaurant of Michelin class.
Unfortunately, they don’t have their own restrooms, and the ones within the market place, with all the other restaurants, was sort of horrible (see pics).
This, however is the only downside, in my opinion, and the location does not inflict on my rating.

Tucked behind a discrete door in the District, this should be a foodie Mecca. The staff is attentive, informative and fun. The room is small and intimate but not stuffy and claustrophobic. You have privacy. The food, as part of a set menu, just keeps coming. Every morsel is delicious. You can taste every flavour. We had the wine pairing which was creative and delicious, perfectly matched. The staff knew their stuff and were proud and happy to talk about it. My husband and I hope to go back soon.

Tucked away behind a supermarket door (see also Chef's Table at Brooklyn Fare), an intimate space (L'Appart means the apartment) with an open kitchen, or at least service kitchen.
A fixed menu of several courses of hors d'oeuvres (chef Nicolas "Nico" Abello's snacks), three savoury dishes, a cheese choice (with a supplement) then three dessert dishes. 
Awarded one Michelin star in the 2017 list and this is where it fairly sits. A pleasant evening with good service and good food.

Review titles: One of the best dining choices in the city

Review text: Once you found the restaurant inside the “Le District” center @Liberty Street you are welcomed by the smiling and attentive staff. The tasting menu is set and changes monthly, the wine pairing and caviar are optional. And then your taste buds are in for a rare and outstanding adventure. The combination of food items, consistency, colors and flavors in each dish is made with great creativity. We counted nine dishes and also chose the cheese. We will return!

It’s difficult to sum up my experience at L’Appart. Everything was exquisite and far above my expectations, from the greeting at the front door, which included a handshake and a glass of Doblin dry vermouth on ice, from the wine and drink options (optional pairings is definitely the way to go), to the modern, artsy decor, to the warm, cozy, apartment like feel to the one room restaurant—every part of your dining experience is thoroughly thought out, and hand-tailored to you with unparalleled quality and the finest presentation imaginable. Chef Nico recently earned his first Michelin star for his performance since the restaurants inception only a few short years ago. And based on the breadth of his talent, I imagine his Michelin recognition will not end here. Look up professional critic reviews for further confirmation of the utter, complete excellence present in his craft. Nico brings French fine dining to you, and you don’t want to miss out on experiencing the culinary finesse of this budding chef. Words aren’t enough—you have to experience L’Appart for yourself.

Amazing and Fabulous -- everything you want in a fancy restaurant.  It's a tasting menu experience, no ala carte, but there were no disappointments!  They even had an optional white truffle course for the season.   Service was impeccable too. Nice little establishment, only about 10...More

Amazing and Fabulous -- everything you want in a fancy restaurant. It's a tasting menu experience, no ala carte, but there were no disappointments! They even had an optional white truffle course for the season. Service was impeccable too. Nice little establishment, only about 10 tables. In an interesting location, in the middle of Le District, which is an upscale food court. Highly recommend.

A terrific experience - the setting is super relaxing and the service was spot on. We had the tasting menu (the only option) and my husband had the wine pairing which he loved. While I didn’t get wine, the staff went out of their way to give me champagne and dessert wine (I didn’t ask for this) so my husband had drinking company. They also handed us champagne when we arrived and even accommodated us 15 minutes early, when we arrived early thinking our reservation was 1/2 hour earlier than it actually was. Definitely one of the best restaurants on Seated!

Trying to figure out the right words for this experience, the staff was amazing, the food was so thought out and unique. We chose the three plate tasting and though I felt it was too much food for me, my husband had no problem. Take it easy on the snacks so you can really enjoy your dinner. They had homemade butter with delicious bread, I tasted every dish and one was better than the next. They made special accommodations for my shell fish allergy, and called before the reservation to check. We dealt with every member of the dining room and the service was impeccable. The Chef makes his rounds to all the tables to make sure you are happy. We were celebrating our anniversary and they made us feel special. My husband had the wine paring and loved it, he tried some new wines and learned along the way. We will be back for sure! My favorite dish was the black sea bass, and my husband loved the pasta course. The desserts were spectacular as well, I loved every morsel of food I was served. It is truly an intimate and incredible setting with an divine selection of food.

My wife treat me there for my b-day. At first it seems expensive, up there with the top new york eateries, but at the end they give you much more than the competition. After reviewing their menu online, i was ready to choose one item of each group, appetizers, plats and desserts, but to my delight ALL was part of the tasting menu. We got to taste 6 appetizers, 3 main courses and 2 desserts, plus some chef extras. The wine pairing had no less than 7 wines. Pricey yes, but worth it for a special occasion. Food was excellent and service impeccable, highly recommended.

We had dinner at L’appart for my husband’s birthday. He works in Brookfield place where the restaurant is located so it wasn’t a lot of travel for us but it is worth it to come all the way downtown for this. The restaurant is hidden in Le District but is not too hard to find. Once you pass the wooden doors you feel like you are in a different world. The restaurant is styled after a chef’s apartment and it does feel very cozy and homey (if your home was a fabulously decorated Michelin restaurant). The staff is excellent, attentive and on point with their timing but not overbearing. They had a personalized menu for my husband’s birthday and brought a lovely dessert at the end. We did not do the wine pairing since we had a few cocktails before but had an amazing bottle of Chardonnay, Domaine leflaive Macon Verze. We loved it so much that the staff helped us find it at a local wine shop and we picked up a few bottles of our own. The food was truly amazing and paced perfectly, we did not feel rushed or overly full. Some standouts were the savory panna cotta, tortellini and duck. We added on the salmon special which was delicious. My husband’s favorite thing was the butter and he put it on everything. It was definitely a memorable birthday experience and I know we will be back!

The restaurant is a no tip restaurant. Everyone works together to make sure you are served attentively. We sat in the tavern portion and LOVED our food. The beet salad, flatbread, and chicken (yes it really is THAT good) were some of the best I've ever eaten. Not to be outdone the pumpkin bengie and pudding cake were soooo good.

GramercyTavern was highly recommenced by foodie friends and was wonderful (they do have one Michelin star). There are two rooms with different menus for lunch: front room by the bar for drop-ins (a la carte), and back room with reservations (a la carte or prix fix tasting menus). Decor is surprising for NYC: CA rancho style with high vaulted ceilings, very peaceful and relatively quiet. Tables are widely spaced, and service outstanding, making an unusually pleasant dining experience. 
Good range of entrees and appetizers, all very tasty and beautifully plated. You can make special requests for dish alterations. Good, but pricey wine list. Lovely, crisp salads and very good fresh-baked rolls. We had 4 popular entrees, and rated them: superb burger, excellent schnitzel, very good char and tile fish. Dessert menu looks fabulous, but we had no room. 
Expensive, but very well worth it for special occasions. Tips and coatcheck included in prices. Lunch about $50 each without alcohol. Highly recommended.
We had a late lunch here and left even more disappointed that it was our last day in NYC. Great decor, tremendous food and service. Very  reasonably priced and it’s a no tipping establishment.

Hard to get reservation.  Now they offer same/similar food in bar area as the price fix meal in the dining room. our flight got delayed quite a bit and we missed our dining room reservation but ate in bar instead.  Because of that, they served...More

It’s no tipping restaurant. The restaurant was great decoration, food was lovely! We understand that service a little bit slow as it’s busy. They all handled well. Dish we love is Wagyu meatball. Thanks to the Chef who made our request as my husband is non dairy. Carrot purée was awesome!

Food and drinks were good but not outstanding. What was outstanding was the desert which was a raspberry passion fruit tort. It was to die for. Service was not good. Too many different people coming to table and never our waiter who knew we had a 8pm show! He was MIA for last half hour! Come on GT this is your 25th year, not your 25th day.
Really exceptional food and service in a non-intimidating atmosphere. Festive sound level. Casual dress code.

Hard to get reservation. Now they offer same/similar food in bar area as the price fix meal in the dining room. our flight got delayed quite a bit and we missed our dining room reservation but ate in bar instead. Because of that, they served many of their dining room entrees to us in bar. They were all great. had been wanting to try this place for quite some time.

Review titles: Service not in line with a Michelin star

Review text:
We came here on the recommendation of a colleague and were not disappointed. 
Although we had to wait aproximately 30 minutes for a table at lunch time (we didnt have a reservation), it was no problem as they have a comfortable waiting area and staff kept us updated on progress of our table.
Once seated we had a great dining experience, with bubbly tavern atmosphere, very friendly and helpful service and exceptional food and wine. I made a special request for the Wagyu meatballs due to my dairy allergy and the waitress (I cant remember her name, but she was awesome) organised this with the kitchen and the result was amazing....it ended up being one of my favourite meals while in NY.
Highly recommended.

Review titles: One of the Best of NYC

Review text: First (and likely only) time dining at the Gramercy Tavern. The meal itself was fine (aside from a very salty chicken) but left very disappointed with our careless server. He never introduced himself, seemed not interested at all in engaging with the table, was mostly MIA (20 min between main dish and dessert felt like forever) and never acknowledged the birthday we were celebrating. The support staff did bring a cake with a generic “happy birthday” written on the plate despite the fact that I was specifically asked for the name of the birthday person when confirming the reservation the day before. When you’re spending $350 for a meal for two you do get to expect some personal touch to the occasion but there was none whatsoever. Not sure if it’s the no-tipping policy that ends up resulting in this very mediocre service. Not interested in coming back.

A favorite place for us, well trained staff and generally well executed. Food is outstanding! They do not rush you here if you would like to linger or go at a relaxed pace.
The only nit is that our waiter left our table to other staff, in his haste he neglected to adjust the bill for wines that we tasted, but refused.

Review titles: Noise and Good Food don't go together

Review text: The Clocktower is a beautiful spot next to Madison Square park. I joined some friends for dinner which was thoroughly enjoyable. The sourdough for the table was excellent. The burrata was nice but felt like more of a spring dish. The tomato salad was excellent. I had a fish that was quite good. But we were too full for dessert. Service is attentive and the decor is lovely.

I guess the decor was meant to resemble an old restaurant with pictures hung all over the walls and a lot of dark wood. I was predisposed not to like the place and then the freshly baked sourdough arrived followed by the roasted cauliflower dish,...More

Great location and layout but the menus are super misleading. For example, what was billed as Sheppard's Pie was in fact an interestingly prepared chicken breast with a small, not very interesting, pie on the side. Strange attempt to make everything sound English in an attempt to be sophisticated. Better to just rename the dishes. Costs nothing and improves service.

The Clocktower is an elegant restaurant, and my wife and I were looking forward to an excellent dinner and some great conversation about many things we had not been able to talk about because of our divergent schedules.
Overall, although the food was of good quality, the noise level in the restaurant was such that a normal conversation was hardly possible. I really liked the pasta with oxtail, 3 cheeses and truffle. My wife's main course was good but not really all that special; and the service was slow, as if we were an after-thought. On the positive side, the waiter gave us (in brought strokes) the recipe for my dish. We have tried it at home and it worked out great.
Bottom-line: I am sure they are on to something in that place; but we have decided not to go back there, as a normal conversation was not possible with the noise level; and as a result, we were eating as fast as possible to be able to get out and have a normal conversation somewhere else.
What a waste of their cooking talent and our money....

A lovely atmosphere and surroundings for a great Thanksgiving meal!
Went for thanksgiving day meal from their special thanksgiving day set menu.
The bar area was cosy and full of character and reminded me of an old club in London. A decent range of drinks and cocktails and a good place to have a pre dinner drink.
The restaurant area was lovely and sat in front of the fire you would have thought you were in a small cosy London club. The turkey dinner was excellent with good portions and we were provided with a gift to leave.
Would recommend
Happy thanksgiving

Had been here a few times. The last one wasn't so great but figured to give it another shot. My burata was somewhat dry, but main course (burger) was delicious. My dining companions both had the heirloom tomatoes for appetizers and they were good, alogn with their cods. The Apple crumble desert was OK...a more traditional one would had been better. Service was very good. Sommelier was wonderful.

Went there for a drink before dinner.
Nice bar, not much of a scene but still has a nice vibe.
Food looked good

We chose this place because of its location and its Starr affiliation. We had a delicious meal and stellar service. The ambiance is perfect — clubby with loads of interesting photos all up and down the walls. A great start to a lovely day in NYC.

I guess the decor was meant to resemble an old restaurant with pictures hung all over the walls and a lot of dark wood. I was predisposed not to like the place and then the freshly baked sourdough arrived followed by the roasted cauliflower dish, see below. By then I was convinced the place was worth its star.
Interesting restaurant with a good menu - not huge but good. Well-designed restaurant with a smaller bar. Very pleasant evening.

Having eaten at le Gaveroche, hand and flowers, midsummer house, fat duck and others we were expecting great things and were bitterly disappointed. The restaurant was noisy the food was mediocre and underwhelming. The service was no better than a chain restaurant with no attention to detail - poor and 4 disappointed ladies

I visited the dining room in January 2020. This was really one of the best meals I have had in awhile. The service was exceptional, and everything was delicious.
I am also happy to see they have been doing their best to deliver and provide...More

Dear Michael White, Book a flight to Ireland, check into the Merrion hotel Dublin & go for dinner in Patrick Guilbaud's to open your eyes to true two Michelin Star quality. 
The food at Marea was distinctly average, presentation was not pleasing. Service was ok not Michelin Star quality. Very disappointing.
The restaurant was excellent: service perfect; wine list excellent and approachable; food glorious. We had a wonderful meal and felt at home there (surprisingly non-pretentious place).

and hard to find fault with the service, and while some dishes were outstanding, I would have expected every dish to shine, and they did not. 
I would not hesitate to recommend this venue for a special occasion as the service was truly 5 star, and I was impressed with a special dessert brought for me as it was my birthday. Perhaps the weakest dish was the one I chose, which was Tagliatelle with Crab. Unfortunately this was a bit salty and there was little crab. On the other hand, the Fusili with Octopus was truly outstanding.

Husband and I came here for brunch for Vday. Overall food was great! The seafood was tasty! It’s definitely what you would expect from a Michelin restaurant. Ambience was just okay and you could hear other people’s conversation but the food makes up for it. The tastes of each dish are interesting and different. I would definitely recommend for the food.

I visited the dining room in January 2020. This was really one of the best meals I have had in awhile. The service was exceptional, and everything was delicious.
I am also happy to see they have been doing their best to deliver and provide their fantastic food to people, during the pandemic. One of the rare favorable things that came from all this is that I now have some time to give them the great review they deserve.

In a city that offers a wide range of dining experiences, Marea earns its star.
This restaurant’s take on Italian seafood is a different approach to more traditional Italian food offered by most others. The offerings we sampled were all memorable. Creatively prepared and presented. Wonderful flavors that tantalize the palate.
Service was superb. Our waiter was helpful in navigating the menu and making selections. Was available but not hovering. Made the dining experience even more special.

The fusilli is the crowd favorite but personally, I loved the gnochetti and the garganelli. The Rosemary was perfectly balanced in the gnochetti that it gave it something special without being overpowering. The truffle was also very good with the garganelli. The fusilli was obviously good but I would take the other two first. 
When talking apps, the lobster burrata is another crowd pleaser. Creamy burrata covered with lobster, what could be wrong with that?
And for dessert, if you like doughnuts, the bomboloni is the way to go. If you like Magnum ice cream bars then you should definitely order the semifreddo. 
Marea is a class of it's own and I feel silly for waiting this long to visit. It's delicious and an amazingly good time.

I often walk by this restaurant and admire the lovely decor and classy ambiance. So, when my husband asked what I wanted for my birthday, I said, "Lunch at Marea!" From the moment we walked in the door, we were made welcome and comfortable. When I made the reservation, I mentioned it was my birthday and I would love a window seat if that was possible. Voila! Sat by the window. When the meal was finished, the waiter brought a little piece of cake with a candle in it - a lovely surprise.
The service here is extraordinary, unobtrusive and efficient. The fish I ordered was cooked perfectly and my husband's duck ravioli were delicious. The cocktails also were excellent.
This is a great special occasion place. If you want to impress someone, bring him or her here.

A fabulous lunch ! 
From the minute you walk in to the minute you leave you will not be disappointed. 
An extensive wine list with a cracking little Sancerre at $85.

Our waiter gave us recommendations on the pasta dishes and they were flawless.

This has now jumped into the top 3 restaurants visited and easily the best pasta dish I’ve ever tasted. 

No matter what you are celebrating , or not, it’s a must visit place.

Three of us dined on Monday, February 10th. One of us had the four-course, and the other two ate a bit lighter... The service was impeccable, with dishes coming at just the right time and served to the right person! (Why can't more restaurants do this?) The sommelier was able to help with wine selection and his recommendations were right on. We will definitely return and look forward to further exploring the exquisite menu.

Review titles: Amazing food - Bouley stellar quality in a new location

Review text:
Here are the highlights of our Christmas Eve dinner:
1. They were 30 min late seating us. 
2. An amateur host asked the four of us
to follow him to our table, only to tell us in the middle of dining room that he had made a mistake and the table was not ready. Go back and wait. 
3. To their credit, they did offer free drinks while we were waiting. 
4. The FIRST food item to arrive (amuse bouche) arrived at the table at 950 pm for an 830 reservation.
5. The manager apologized but the poor service continued. Had to ask for bread 3 times before it arrived 15 min after the amuse bouche. Then they kept serving bread nonstop which became annoying given 30+ min intervals between the servings of tiny portions for this multi-course meal. 
6. At ~$200 per person without drinks, they mismatched the food -person three times!
7. The food was OK to good. None of the food items were amazing. Desserts were exceptional.
8. We had been to the old Bouley several times and thought it was much better than its rivals at the time ( Jean Georges, Daniel, etc.). This experience reversed all that. Sadly, this was emblematic of a talented chef lured by greed and the prospects of wealthy tourists blindly splurging on mediocrity. 
9. Will not return.

I would have to agree with the last review (Xanadu in NJ). 
First, my heart sank when I walked into the space. It looks like a wealthy granny’s dining room. None of the old high polish and grandeur of the old Boulez. The cookbooks adorning the wall of the barn-like space are lovely but seem as though they were thrown in willy nilly.
The well meaning coat checker was busy with something else so we stood in limbo between the front door and Chef Boulez who had been accosted by a gaggle of tittering Chinese ladies. We barely got a glance from him as we finally squeezed through. Then, no official greeting (it seems there is no Maitre d’ Hotel) from anyone. We stood awkwardly waiting for ten minutes for a table despite several suited gentleman officially prowling the room. 
Things got better. The prix fixe was a good deal for a six course dinner. That it ran from 9-12 was not surprising but slightly irritating, A as I was guaranteed when I made my reservation that we would leave in time to catch a midnight mass. 
We were treated well and in a professional manner. The food, our reason for being there, was excellent in every way. The portions are perfect, the attention to detail, phenomenal, the tastes, surprising and good.
Two pet peeves: the white light board above the kitchen emits a harsh glare and casts an un homey light on the dining room and the kitchy screens and old fashioned heavy furniture. 
Should you go, ask you a seat by the kitchen.

Food good but overall experience unacceptable. We were a party of 4 - one upholstered chair was so wet that it soak through one of our guests slacks. The Captain had an arrogant attitude even when we tried to engage her in conversation. She reviewed the menu with us and was told that one guest does not eat pork or shellfish (had also completed the on-line information about this ahead of time) and nonetheless she was served iberico ham, calamari with the halibut and specifically told the captain no calamari.
Another had told the Captain he has an allergy to mangos and nonetheless was served hamachi with mango.
We advised the M’aitre D’hui of this who was very apologetic and thankful but did nothing else to make it right except offer a glass of sauterne at 10:40 when we wanted to leave.
Careless systems and people.
For a 1000.00 meal this was an inferior experience.

After many years grinding in NY, Bouley still delivers in a quite different way than many others. Now where everyone is using and abusing acids and strong flavors, he dont. He still using sublime not overpowering flavor. From the Fish Piperade manner to the Lobster, Duck, Sea Urchin in Apple Cloud.
All of them flavorful but not agressive in the mouth at all, you just notice the ingredients they way he seems to intend you to do so.
 A quick grind would come out of your face when you start tasting. Im glad he still at it.

We had friends in town and wanted to take them to a special lunch. We chose Bouley at Home which was offering a late lunch. The tasting menu was 3 or 5 courses. We opted for the latter with a bottle of wine. Everything was delicious. Service was impeccable. Timing was not too long or short between courses. The bread was a beautiful accompaniment to the dishes and they had 6 different offerings. The hall is also quite lovely though given the late hour it was empty.

Review titles: Once again a fine dining experience - even at lunch

Review text: My friend and I had the three course Prix Fixe lunch today. All the food was outstanding. The restaurant is very flexible, and allowed me to have two appetizers and a main course instead of appetizer, main course, and dessert. I had the sautéed mixed mushrooms with Toro, which was amazingly flavorful. My second appetizer was the porcini flan, that comes with crab meat, another complex flavor and texture wonder. For the main course, we both had the duck which was tender slices of duck breast accompanied by wild rice, purée, and a delicious sauce. Before we were served dessert, we were given a pre-– dessert course which was coconut soup with vanilla and passion fruit gelato with pieces of preserved pineapple – amazing and refreshing. We were then served two more desserts, an extra for me because it was my birthday. The chocolate walnut cake with sorbet on the side was moist and frankly just perfect. My friend had a chocolate cake with gelato on the side, which she pronounced terrific. An added touch was a plate of chocolates, and then as we left the restaurant we were each handed a little shopping bag that had a muffin from their bakery. All in all a fantastic dining experience.

Review titles: One of NY finest still delivers..

Review text:
Bouley at Home is next to the Bouley Test Kitchen, which primarily hosts special events. Bouley at Home is a well-lit, intimate but busy, space. Several tables for two line one wall (perfect for romantic dinners). Two counters also accommodate diners, (where one can chat with a friend or two, and/or watch the chefs-perhaps even converse with them.
After my husband was extremely pleased with his first dinner at Bouley at Home, he rushed to reserve a table for us to celebrate our 35th wedding anniversary. We ordered the 7 course tasting menu. Don't be fooled by the number of courses. The portions were perfectly sized for flavor and texture, and one should not feel overly stuffed-just pleasantly satisfied.
This is definitely fine-dining, just right for a special day.
The service and servers were exemplary. Each bite of food was an exquisite pleasure. 
We will definitely return for more dinners.

Christmas Prix Fixe Dinner! Each course expertly prepared in a very relaxing atmosphere. Our table was located close to the open kitchen. We were able to watch Chef David and his very professional staff prepare dishes for a packed house. It was a rare gift. Over the years we had eaten at Bouley because of the exceptional dining experience... this new experience was the same.
We look forward to the next Bouley adventure.

We always go back. The menu changes and two of our favourites are no longer on the list but everything was so good it didn't matter.
Kobe beef cheeks in different form but still delicious. Shrimp was great.

Pros:  the service is great - very attentive.  The staff was extremely knowledge regarding gluten-free options and Celiac Disease for my husband.  
Cons: even for four people, it was basically a pre fixe menu for the entire table.  Be prepared to be there for a...More

My partner and I were celebrating her birthday and we were staying nearby to Del Posto so we thought we'd give it a try. It was relatively easy to get a last minute reservation on a Monday night, so we were in luck. They even followed up with a call to confirm the reservation and ask about any special requests. From the minute you walk in you can tell this is a classy place. The decor and lighting and the professionalism of the staff make you feel a little like royalty. We went with the five course Il Menu Del Posto with the wine pairing. We were waited on by several people, all extremely courteous, knowledgeable and friendly. Our sommelier was particularly memorable. He clearly knows his business very well and seems to really enjoy his work. The dishes that came out were each more delicious than the last and the presentation was excellent. To give you an idea of just how much we enjoyed the food: the bread and butter (whipped in house) were actually amazing. I've never had butter both so tasty and so light. They topped off the evening with a lovely dessert with a candle and with happy birthday written on it. Very nice touch indeed. Overall, the service was impeccable, the food was delicious and the ambiance was perfect. They even gave us some tips for an after dinner beverage nearby. They have definitely earned their Michelin star.

Pros: the service is great - very attentive. The staff was extremely knowledge regarding gluten-free options and Celiac Disease for my husband. 
Cons: even for four people, it was basically a pre fixe menu for the entire table. Be prepared to be there for a while - we were there for over 3 hours. The portions are very small - just when we started liking a dish, it was gone. 
Overall, I’d say the dining experience was what it was all about and that was good. My friend wore jeans so the dress code is not enforced. Considering all of the options in NYC, I don’t believe we will be back to Del Posto.

Review titles: Eating here? Take out a second mortgage!

Review text: We ate here on a long weekend trip to New York. From start to finish, it was an amazing experience. The setting is fantastic and feels really special, unlike many restaurants I visit in London that have no atmosphere. The tables are really well spaced. We started with a couple of cocktails at the bar and then had a tasting menu with wine pairings. Both the food and wine was exceptional. The only warning is that it is not cheap, so check the menu prices before going.

A late December lunch and Del Posto delivered on all fronts. The room, the service and the food were terrific. It felt much like a fine dining experience in Rome or Venice and each course was delicious and elegant. Local or visitor you’ll enjoy this grand experience.

Del Posto is an absolutely beautiful old-style Italian restaurant with perfect service. We had the $69 prix-fixe lunch, which was a great deal, actually (but see the caution below.). We were greeted by a waiter who had memorized our food restrictions, and brought heated towels scented with tomato vines. For appetizers, we had: Arctic Char trio - crudo with Osetra caviar, light confit with parsley root puree, and tartare with great celery root chips;.and vitello tonnato with fried shallots and colatura sauce. My secondi was short ribs ($20 extra) with spinach, roasted mushrooms, a polenta foam, and red wine veal jus. Hers was chicken with a mild truffle jus - the thigh meat was breaded and fried, and the breast meat had an artichoke stuffing. For dessert, I had a vanilla and forbidden rice panna cotta with pear and black sesame sorbet, while she had a semi-firm ricotta with olive oil crackers. They also brought us several fancy chocolates at the end. The food was beautifully prepared and delicious. 
A caution on the price: It's easy to boost it by a lot. I chose the one entree with a surcharge, and bottled still or sparkling water can run you $10 apiece, and their wine list can get pricey as well. If you're on a strict budget, stay in control on these items. But even so, this restaurant was a trip highlight, no question.

Fabulous! Deserves the Michelin Star that it already has. We had the 5 course dinner on a wintry Sunday night. All 5 courses were marvelous! Having said that, the linguine with geoduck was my favorite, followed closely by the veal/tuna/sweetbread appetizer. Pork agnolotti and branzino were also delicious. A delightful marscapone tartuffo capped off the meal. My dining partner had the Arctic char appetizer which was Italian style sashimi. Her entree was the 28 day aged ribeye, with hazelnut cake topped with gelato. The 2 pastas (linguine and agnolotti) are shared by the table. Great time. Highly recommend!

The restaurant is as beautiful as advertised. The food and service were spectacular. The check was also spectacular but that was expected. The perfect place to introduce our son to the art of fine dining. Watching him absorb it all was more than worth it.
The food and service here was very good. We would definitely come back here someday. One of the best restaurants we ate in New York, worth the price

The best italian restaurant in New York city!
Excellent guest service, wine and food.
It’s a place where every penny expanding has the right value!

Dinner for 2 with a comparatively inexpensive wine (from wine list - restaurant does not permit bringing your own wine) cost us $800.
Price fix dinner only.

Wait staff was outstanding. Food was good, not spectacular which it should have been for the price. 

Atmosphere is lovely but definitely NOT worth price of admission,

Having been to many omakase restaurants in NYC and living in NYC all my life I was skeptical of a few things. First, they are in midtown and midtown is notorious for catering to the tourist crowd and second, the two Michelin stars as Michelin has been very strange lately with giving out the honors. Long story short, the only good thing about the meal was the excellent rice. The fish was average quality and not worth the 300 price tag. The flavor profiles were non existent. In fact, with drinks and taxes it came out to 450 a person. Definitely not worth the money and I left hungry which is very unusual. I can safely say that I would never go back to this place. There are many better omakase restaurants with a much lower price. And I’ll definately stay away from midtown from now on.

My friend and I treat ourselves at least once a year to a super special Omakase experience in NYC, and after seeing the 2 Michelin stars, we had to try this. 
With some of the other places we’ve tried recently- Shuko... Sushi Azabu to name a few - where almost every bite had our eyes rolling back with pleasure and having some of the best and flavorful bites at a sushi restaurant, SGO could have been any ordinary sushi place.
There wasn’t anything we ate on this $300 Omakase that I would describe as great. From the appetizers, that were just ok... and some with odd flavors... to the nigiri course...it just left me annoyed to pay that price and not be blown away.

Heads up, the restaurant may be a little difficult to find because there might still be scaffolding’s covering the sign. When you do find it you’ll walk into a wooden cube where you’ll confirm your reservation. For lunch I was seated at the bar and it was one sushi chef for every four guests. Had some varieties Fish I’ve never had before sushi or otherwise. Heads up thatThe chefs however are a limited in their English, and you won’t be having extended conversations with them, not in English at least. I didn’t like that the waitress served from behind meaning I had to lean back or turn sideways to get beverages etc. It’s definitely on the much higher end of sushi restaurants for $120 for 12 pieces of sushi with one or two appetizers and one dessert plus sake. Still I always wanted to eat here and I did enjoy my experience, not sure that I will be going back anytime soon though, one of those checked the box experiences. If it’s on your check the box List I highly recommend you do it. Lunch starts at $100 for 10 pieces plus some extras, but dinner starts at 300$ I believe.

Great atmosphere. it was my 3rd time. 
It is expensive but worth the money.
Great place for a special occasion.

Review titles: Chinese New year Eve Special celebration

Review text: A sushi place like Onodera is unique. I have travelled the world and had sushi in Japan, South East Asia and of course United States in fantastic places. But Onodera is just unique and deserves its 2 Michelin macarons.

This is our first time to visit this restaurant and the service is incredible. Although the pricing is in the high side, it worths every penny.
The sever is very attentive and the chef knows how to entertain us. My son was sleeping most of...More
I had 15pcs sushi, my friend had 13pcs, my order is nothing special compared with my friend order. person next to me had 10pcs, very bad: no otoro, chutoro, uni; the best choice is 13pcs!

I came here due to a food blog which listed this place 2nd only to Masa. That really got my attention because Masa is damn good even though it is damn expensive.
I came here on a weekday and noticed it was pretty empty with only five ppl so more than half the table is empty. It was weird because Open Table only had one open time. This is not a good sign as other competitors are packed on a similar weekday.
The ambiance is what you would expect at a traditional Omakase. Very bright and very minimalistic. I know this is typical Omakase but it’s boring and I don’t like it.
Overall, the food is high quality. The toro is amazing but not better than Shuko or even Nakazawa. I definitely had better toro elsewhere. The eel sushi is no good and over cooked and tasted like slush. Best eel is at 15 East. The real stars here are the miso soup and green tea. These are the best I ever had.
After about $500, I was still hungry but luckily a KFC is nearby and still open. At this price point, it’s cheaper than Masa but I was quite full after eating at Masa. This price does not even include drink pairing while you can get Omakase and drink pairing for the same price at Shuko - quite a bargain. For better bang for the buck, skip the drink pairing at Shuko or even opt for sushi only since they are by far the stars of the entire meal.
Ultimately, amazing sushi but bad value. It could be because the fish is flown in from Japan. Not really worth paying for since the fish here is good enough.

This is our first time to visit this restaurant and the service is incredible. Although the pricing is in the high side, it worths every penny.
The sever is very attentive and the chef knows how to entertain us. My son was sleeping most of the time as we travelled from HK, they offered off menu to my boy.
They only served omakase and they hv shipment to New York. The fish is truly amazing. We will definitely visit again.

My wife and I celebrated 10 years of being together this March, and since we are both big omakase sushi fans, we thought Sushi Ginza Onodera would be a great place to commemorate the occasion.

It was such an amazing meal! Every part of the service was wonderful and in line with my expectations for a two-star Michelin restaurant. Appetizers were varied, unique, and delicious - highlights for me were the egg custard with hokkaido uni and white truffle, and the baby squid stuffed with miso paste.

The actual omekase was wonderfully paced - we didn't feel rushed or hurried, the chef was wonderfully conversational and paid attention to little details (left-handed people were served with the fish facing the right way, women first, good descriptions of what was being served, etc.) The quality of fish was very good - everything was an adventure, texture-wise, and the flavors really popped on some items: Black Seaperch with horseradish, Sardine, Akami (lean tuna), Cherry Blossom Trout stood out.

They brought out two glasses of champagne at the end of the meal for our celebration along with a macha-bean pudding - very tasty.

Onodera, located on Fifth Ave, is a perfect spot to have dinner after a shopping trip in midtown. The space is small with a few tables and the sushi bar. We were seated at the sushi bar where we could watch each piece being carefully prepared. Watching the chef work is part of the whole experience. I enjoyed everything but my favourites were the uni, the fish liver, and the otoro. Many of the ingredients are brought from Japan. Service is very good and there is a good selection of sake. Quality is very good and I had some fish I haven’t had before. Price is high but then it’s located on Fifth Ave and many ingredients come from Japan.

I did not realize that it was a Michelin star restaurant till I walked into the restaurant and saw the Michelin guide sitting in the entrance. The lunch menu was fairly extensive with lots of hot entrees, as well as sushi/sashimi and various lunch sets. The service was excellent and the staff spent the time explaining the content of each small dishes. I chose a beef lunch set and for $40, I expect a bit more in terms of quantity. Also charging $5 for a cup of tea was a bit more, if they are charging $40 for a lunch set. 
While the lunch was okay, I actually think dinner might be a better experience. $120/170 omakaze is not cheap but at least I feel you see the creativity for Japanese cuisine. For Japanese lunch, there are certainly better choices in Soho and the city.
Just came here for dinner and had the 7-course omakase and it was good. The dishes was delicious. Very high quality japanese food.

We had a business dinner of four people. Small capacity restaurant 
Good quality of series of foods from start to finish
Could enjoy season via the food
Counter table faces Itamae which might be good for two people for quiet settings

Went there for a business lunch with a customer. We were really blown away by the quality of the omakase. 
If you compare with similar omakase in the City, the value is unbelievable. I will definitely go back there. Great service, great food.

Just came back from dinner at Hirohisa and it was one of the best Japanese restaurants we've been to in NYC. We did 7-course omakase and every dish was delicious. They were each very well balanced in flavor and beautiful presentation. The amount of food seemed small but by the end of the meal my husband I were both stuffed. The service was top notch and it was fun to sit at the bar watching chefs at work. Very well deserved of 1 Michelin Star. I would love to try the 9-course omakase next time we visit.

Review titles: Chef Hirohisa is a gem - great birthday and a truly authentic Japanese experience in NYC
New York has very good japanese restaurants

Review text:
New York offers very good high quality Japanese omakase and many of my meals while visiting NYC are invariably Japanese. The ingredients are either from Japan or sourced from the USA. Uni for example may be from Santa Barbara or Hokkaido.
Having trawled the internet, Hirohisa came up and off we went to try it. Soothing, low light interiors and pleasant service. Ordered the omakase which was quite good but not excellent.

We went for a special birthday dinner celebration and had the Omakase with sake pairings. The food was very good, in particular the chawan-mushi and sashimi. The portions were quite small -- maybe we paid $5/bite. Glad I went, need to save up for a return in a few years' time. The place is very small too -- not really any atmosphere. And it was fairly empty on the weeknight we went.

Overall the food was ok, fairly small plates for the price you're paying. Sushi was really good, the meat was ok. We've been to many Michelin Star restaurants and this one didn't quite make the grade. I'm sure we would have had a better experience had the waitress not been giving my daughter an evil eye the whole time, telling her to "shh....." despite the fact there was only 1 other couple in the restaurant for most of the dinner and she was on her best behavior. I just felt uncomfortable the entire time and, in the end, was ready to leave as quickly as they gave me the bill (which was before we even said we were finished or finished my drink).

Took my wife here for her birthday dinner, and made the reservation 2 weeks in advance to be seated at the bar where we can observe Chef Hirohisa preparing the various dishes. The experience was one of the best in a Japanese restaurant in NYC we've had, which is a high bar given the number of excellent venues in the city. 
The venue was hidden, sleek, and modern. We opted for the 7-course pre-fixe, and ended up getting an amusee as well as extra Soba noodles at no cost. It was plenty of food but there is a 9-courses option if you are extra hungry. The dishes were very well-paced and generally progressed from more "raw" (sashimi, wrapped scallops" to more "cooked" (shrimp head tempura, final dish was a wagyu steak) which was one of the many times we noticed Hirohisa's meticulous attention to detail. The dishes were all extremely delicious and high-quality, with the standouts being the shrimp head sashimi (part of the arctic shrimp in the sashimi tasting), eel rice, wagyu steak, and all the desserts in the final platter. 
The best part of the night, perhaps, was talking to Chef Hirohisa after things quieted down a bit late at night. We chatted and asked him about his favorite restaurants back home in Japan (as we are visiting in a few months) - he ended up emailing us later that night with a long list of his favorites, including tough-to-find-for-foreigners local joints as well as restaurants ran by his cousin (in the Four Seasons Tokyo, so definitely not too shabby!) We were very impressed and thankful that he took time out of his own schedule to help us plan our trip, which we think really speak to the Chef's character beyond being a genius in the kitchen.
Thank you Hirohisa for a fantastic experience and we will definitely be back!

Review titles: If you are planning on bringing kids... don't
Nice lunch but not sure if this is Michelin star worthy

Review text: Very serene restaurant with absolutely terrific food, both the sushi and the Waygu beef.  Make a point of making it to Soho for this restuarrant alone.

It took me many years to understand *how much* better the best sushi is than standard average, yeah it's OK sushi... Since I worked it out (mostly through having my mind blown by 2 and 3 Michelin star restaurants in Japan) the distinction is very clear. And Satsuki is easily, easily on the right side of the divide. Yeah, it's really expensive. But it's also easily as good, if not better, than anything else you can get in this city and country. As good as the best in Tokyo? Almost. As good as you can get anywhere else here? Yeah, probably... Really enjoyed the sashimi, and the sushi was sublime.

At the very end of basement, there's a sushi bar - if you are a guest of Suzuki, till you go to the rest room, you may not notice there. It is hidden- and a gem.
Only 10 seats at the sushi bar.
The decoration is very simple but unique and it's full of zen atmosphere. 
The sushi chef's sharp knife sparkles when cutting the fresh raw fish.
The performance - I mean, the sequence of making sushi is so elegant, I really gazed all the time and forgot to talk with people who I was with.
The fresh fish may not be a surprising thing at NY's authentic Japanese sushi restaurant.
But I must say this- their egg is beyond amazing. Truly, it is quite difficult to find this level of egg slice even in Japan. Just two thumbs up and that certainly tells the high standard of sushi restaurant. 
Sushi chef is also very knowledgeable - knows all the origins and why.
The conversation of sushi chef also tells about the restaurant's authenticity. He knows from ingredients to type of knife or even ceramics.
Satsuki is 100% excellent sushi restaurant that I can proudly endorse all sushi lovers.

First off, if you have never been to a Michelin rated restaurant I suggest you do a bit of research prior. Only the finest quality food and service gets the honor of even being considered so for the gentleman in a prior review who criticized the fact that people are constantly around you, that my friend is the only way to achieve such an award in excellence. This is a restaurant inside a restaurant and you don't go there because it is cheap, rather for the experience.
Second, Omakase is a Japanese phrase that means "I'll leave it up to you". The Chef selects the menu and I believe they fly their sushi in from Japan each day. The quality of their fish is unlike anything I've experienced in my life.
Finally, the amount of time and careful consideration that the Chef takes in preparing each individual piece of sushi is like watching art being made in front of you. His meticulous nature truly made me feel like I was in Japan. The staff is constantly ensuring that you are being given the highest quality of service and I appreciated that.
The restaurant is very expensive, but it is truly a remarkable experience. The bartender makes his uniquely designed specialty drinks and thought simply goes into every detail of this restaurant. Not many places in the US have Michelin rated restaurants so if you have an opportunity to come to this one, and you understand that quality is not cheap, you will not be dissapointed.
Thank you Chef and staff for an amazing experience.

Having always wanted to try an authentic, high end omakase, I was very eager to go to Satsuki! The evening spent there was one of the best meals I have ever had. The experience began in the lounge where Michelly crafted custom-made cocktails based on our preferences. She has a lot of tricks up her sleeve, like freezing various herbs and fruit slices into ice cubes, and the drinks were fantastic! The omakase included numerous courses. One of my favorites was a delicate savory custard. Every bite of sushi and sashimi was buttery and delectable. The level of care put into each bite was astounding. I only wish I could have had more uni sushi-the best uni ever. We paired an excellent cold sake with our meal and it was delightful.

Seating in the sushi bar right in front of master sushi Chef Toshio Suzuki and watching him prepare delicate pieces of Sashimi/sushi/temaki is an incredible experience. Fish quality and freshness was outstanding, rice cooked to perfection and the herbs/salts plus presentation made my dinner a true gourmet experience. It’s been a while since a tried a place like this in NYC. Prices are reasonably for the omakase when compare to other top sushi places in the city.

This was the absolute best quality sushi I have had. The experience of eating each piece right after it was made in front of you was amazing! Expensive but definitely worth it! Service was also excellent!

Excellent service and out of this world sushi. We tried the full omakase sushi dinner and it was worth every penny. The chef’s work was art on a plate, with every last detail taken with careful precision to deliver one of the best meals we have had. So glad we were able to experience this and a great way to celebrate being back in NYC!

We were devastated when Sushi Zen closed last year after 30+ years. While Chef Suzuki had mentioned that he was in the process of finalizing plans for his new location, there was no mention on the website. Thankfully, Satsuki, his 10-person sushi bar in his new restaurant Suzuki, has opened. We ate there during their soft open and were one of only two parties. What a treat. Atmosphere is more upscale, but same highly personalized experience as Sushi-zen sushi bar. There is no place like this in NYC, although I haven't been to Masa. At $250 it isn't for regular dining, but that's the whole point. Hands down the best sushi in NYC.

First off, food was amazing as was the service. I never really tried Sushi Zen even though I pass by it many times but this restaurant did live up to the words of people who been to Sushi Zen and love it.
The entrance is very unassuming and you might even miss it if you're not too careful. You have to take the elevator or stairs down because it's underground on the basement level. The walls are painted black and if you didn't know better, you think you're walking into a night club.
I see the bar to my left or at least some lounge area. To my right is reception and I was greeted with smiles to the sushi table. It can be quite a maze as you have to cross through the main dining area which has the same black walls and ceilings decor.
When I arrived at the sushi bar, it is your standard big wooden table with bar seats across. Usually the table would be made from fine wood but I wouldn't know. The furniture does seem to be of good quality and chairs quite comfortable. It is simple and very zen, as with most sushi bars at any reputable Japanese restaurant but something about here just seems too bare and at times I feel like I was eating at an unfinished basement. The dining area is not any better and the blackness of the walls and ceilings make it feel like backstage of an off-Broadway production.
The decor really drags down my experience. Also it felt really stuffy to always have someone in back of you and instructing you on how and what to eat. Not really a lay-back experience. But I get it, it's Omakase and that's how it works. The chef will always announce the dish and you will always have to eat it immediately or you stop his flow.
I feel this really should be a four circles rating and perhaps you should assume that since I'm a bit tired of Omakase. A jaded sushi-foodie, if you will - that's moi. Will I ever have sushi again? Maybe. But not anytime soon.

Focused on providing the Japanese equivalent of haute cuisine, also known as Kaiseki Ryori, Satsuki is the renowned omakase sushi bar of the Suzuki Hospitality Group. The group defines Kaiseki Ryori as “the ultimate form of Japanese fine dining experience, expressing season with seasonal dishes,” which a lot of restaurants aim yet hardly succeed to achieve. I chose Satsuki simply because I was craving sushi omakase. Like many of my friends living in NYC for a very limited time of their life, I have a list of restaurants I want to visit before I leave this city, and Satsuki was on the list. I usually find the places on Instagram, where I can see the specific location and pictures of the food and the restaurant at once, and save the captured screen on my phone. Among other several sushi omakase places on my list, I chose Satsuki specifically because when I compared the pictures of the inside of the restaurants, Satsuki seemed to be the most suitable place for solo diners: the table seatings and bar seatings are completely separated, and the entrance is far away from the bar seatings, creating a more intimate ambience between the diners and chefs. 
From a hospitality professional’s perspective, I am a hard customer to please: because of my meticulous personality added to my background as a hospitality student, I have a high, strict set of standards in terms of the quality of service I receive as well as the hospitality experience as a whole. Unlike some people who prioritize the taste of food as the absolute standard of evaluating a restaurant, I prioritize the quality of service, and then comes the taste of food. I am aware of how picky I am, so when I visit a restaurant, I try not to expect anything because I know I will not be pleased easily. My first impression of Satsuki was not different from any other ones: no matter what other people acclaimed about this restaurant, I tried not to create any perception about Satsuki. Going into the restaurant, just like I was going into many other restaurants, I was not hoping for the best experience, but I was hoping it not to be the worst experience. 
“Good evening Miss Kim,” greeted the hostess. To be honest, I was surprised. It is not hard to guess that I am the “Miss Kim” that made a reservation for one person at that time, but not a lot of people have the sense to greet me right at the moment I step my foot into the restaurant. I checked my coat and followed the hostess to my seat. The most distinctively different point of Satsuki in terms of interior design when compared to other sushi places is that Satsuki is very modern. Sushi places tend to keep the interior illumination fairly bright in an attempt to make the fish fresher and to emphasize the traditional Japanese designs and settings. On the other hand, Satsuki maintained its dark setting throughout, and the only bright place within the restaurant was the chef’s area. I had always had a stereotypical image of a Japanese restaurant, where every feature has Oriental details, and encountering the modernism that Satsuki was pursuing was quite sensational. 
The bar seating space had ten seats in total, and two of the seats were already occupied when I entered. To respect the other party’s and my privacy, I was seated at the other end of the bar. The other party seemed to be an old couple, who spoke Japanese fluently and therefore had a free conversation with the chef. I was soon welcomed by the entire staff at the restaurant, including the server and the chef, and given the choice of water and other drinks. The server came back with a cup of green tea that I had ordered, and asked to ensure my food preferences and allergies. When I was making a reservation through text message, I was asked in advance about my food preferences and dietary restrictions - that I do not like clam and uni and that I am allergic to lobster - and the menu I wanted. Satsuki had only two menus: full omakase and half omakase, of which I chose the half omakase, and the server was fully aware of my food preferences, allergies, and the menu I had chosen. These details about me are discussed between me and the restaurant prior to my visit, and I obviously expect the staff to be aware of the details every time I visit a high-end restaurant. However, some restaurants fail to meet my expectations in understanding those details - Satsuki was not one of them. 
The most unique component of an omakase menu is that everything, except for miso soup, is directly served by the chef at the bar, not by the server, and at the time of serving, the chef explains the type of fish, other ingredients used, and how to eat it. As soon as the server brought me my green tea, the chef showed me the fish that were prepared for the day, the freshness and sanitation of which left me speechless. The chef surely showed his knowledge about what he was serving, and in the course of discussing what would best substitute the clam- and uni-based dishes, the ones I specified as my un-likes, he came up with different suggestions based on the day’s freshest fish. His professionalism impressed me, and the consequent confidence added even more taste to the already-delicious sushi. Throughout the whole time, the server came close to me to make sure that my cup is not empty, and every time he saw it was empty, he asked if I wanted it to be refilled. Lastly, by observing the way I dine, the chef noticed that I do not tend to have a personal conversation with anyone other than exchange of information about the food, so he respected my privacy and left me alone, which I appreciated very much. Only towards the very end, he asked where I was from, at what other sushi places in NYC I had ever dined, and how I thought of Satsuki. 
The only minor issue issue I had while I was dining was that the chair I was sitting on was slightly shaking. I noticed that after I started eating, so I decided not to bring it up until I was done eating everything. On my way out, the hostess, handing me back my coat, asked if there was anything they could do to improve, and I finally told her about the shaking chair. After listening, she apologized and promised that the next time I come back, I would not have the same problem. Nonetheless, I was already at an ecstatic state from an amazing meal, so I was not thinking that much about the shaking chair - if the service and food had been bad, I would have made a big deal out of it. 
Having lived in the tristate area for ten years, I visited a myriad of restaurants, and as my personal interest in hospitality grew over time, the focus narrowed down to high-end restaurants. Due to my particularity with service quality and taste as mentioned earlier, I hardly recommend restaurants in New York City to anyone, because nothing really comes to my mind instantly. After my experience at Satsuki, however, Satsuki has established itself as the number one restaurant in my mind. I do not enjoy posting pictures of food or restaurant on Instagram, but I uploaded pictures of the sushi, the interior design, and even the bathroom of Satsuki, because I was that impressed. I truly wish more people visited Satsuki and experienced the state-of-art hospitality. And sushi, too, of course.

Sushi Noz is amazing. Period. So during my 10 days visit to NYC, I have visited 5 sushi restaurants. And Sushi Noz turned out to be the best among them. We were dined at the newly opened ash room and totally wow-ed by the experience. Could not wait to try to dine at their main dining room. Yes it was expensive, but trust me it worth every penny. Shortly after our visit I learned that they got their first michelin star. Truly deserved it!

Sushi Noz is the epitome of fine dining -- where you experience the finesse of Japanese edomae omakase in an ambiance that's an aesthetic gem, so wherever you look is delightful to behold. 
Chef Noz is a master of his craft and goes out of his way to create a progression of courses that wow you. He does this with gestural moves reminiscent of a sumi ink painter, with the superlative quality of ingredients, and the dishes he creates.
The best experience at Sushi Noz requires recognizing that it's a temple. The chef is there to please, in the spirit of Japanese omotenashi hospitality. We need to be respectful too. Reciprocally assuming a quiet attentiveness is how to fully experience what you eat. You leave intensely satisfied.

Sushi Noz was by far our favorite meal during a recent trip to NYC. The service was extremely friendly and welcoming. The restaurant itself is beautiful and feels like you've stepped into a different world. We sat in the Ash Room, which was extremely intimate....More

I've been to every good sushi place in New York. I would say for the last few years Sushi Amane has been the undisputed champ, now that honor must go to Sushi Noz. It's a lot closer to Amane than Amane is to the 3rd best, but Noz definitely takes the cake. 
The otsumami alone had me speechless, and I couldn't believe how many flavors and feelings had been unpacked just with the first few dishes. The sommelier is a real gem and knows his stuff, and Chef Noz and everyone there clearly takes their job very seriously, and passionately. The service is phenomenal and they will be on you whenever your glass gets low or your napkin needs refreshing. 
Chef Noz is so creative and there are plenty of wood-fired and charcoaled pieces which just round out the experience. The aged fish is also sublime of course, and really brings the traditional edomae sushi experience to the next level. 
Honestly, you would think you were in Tokyo the whole time at Sushi Noz - and it's on par with some of the best sushi chefs I've dined with in Tokyo. It's that good. Bravo.
10/10

Sushi Noz was by far our favorite meal during a recent trip to NYC. The service was extremely friendly and welcoming. The restaurant itself is beautiful and feels like you've stepped into a different world. We sat in the Ash Room, which was extremely intimate. There are six diners total in the room during a seating and the chef prepares all aspects of the food directly in front of you, while taking the time to explain what you are eating and answering any questions. This was truly an amazing experience and I would eat here again any time!
