Review text:
This is a small Japanese restaurant in the heart of New York.
My friend invited me there when I was in New York in July.
This is like You visited to one of Your friends in one of province in Japan.
Chef Noz brought to New York real atmosphere of Japanese province and taste of real Japanese cuisine.
Every dish and every sushi has his unique taste and technique of preparation.
You will enjoy every detail of restaurant beginning from service, décor, taste of food and sake, atmosphere and of course great performance of Chef Noz.
Thank You Chef Noz !!!

Review titles: One of the best in NY

Review text:
We had to reserve quite a long time in advance. They accepted only 8 persons at a time. 2 rounds per day at 6pm and 9pm. This restaurant got one Michelin star.
We came a bit early. The staff brought us to the counter table. Chef Nozomu came after all 8 guests were seated. 
The menu would change everyday depending on what ingredients the chef found each day.
He prepared food right in front of us. It was like watching a show. Each bite was delicious. We saw how skillful the chef was. He was a nice and good looking chef too.

I found this restaurant listed at the the top for Omakase in NYC on a website and so decided to check it out and it did not disappoint.
You will be charged $300 and change immediately upon making the reservation. This seems weird but then most of these restaurants due to their limited seating will charge your card if you’re a no-show.
From the outside, the architecture is quite traditional. As you go in, you’ll be greeted by greeters in Kimonos and depending on where you sit, the room will look quite traditional and if I didn’t know better, I would think I’m in Japan. It’s quite a transformative experience, that’s for sure, and everything including the food is quite authentic.
However for me, traditional also means really uncomfortable chairs. They had cushions but it didn’t help much as they are quite thin and the chairs quite solid wood. Dining for over two hours in an uncomfortable chair is not really fine dining to me. There is also no music playing in the background so very quiet. You end up hearing other ppl talking though most ppl that night were pretty quiet and so it was a quiet room with a few ppl. I counted around eight chairs.
Once the chef and his assistant comes out, they bow to the customers before starting their master crafted menu. I was fortunate to get Chef Noz himself so quite a special occasion. He seems quite pleasant and courteous but will not hesitate to tell you if you’re eating his sushi the wrong way.
There are good theatrics like showing us this huge bowl of rice and mixing it with soy sauce or showing us a huge piece of Toro or bringing this huge grill out. Definitely, more entertaining than most Omakases but as you eat the food, you realized it’s not just show and this food is amazingly good unlike your local Benihana.

There is a good mix of cooked food and sushi though most of the menu will be sushi. Where other fine Omakases try to experiment by being different, here, the chef just do and does it right. It simply works and is not different for the sake of being different. Dishes like baby octopus on top of diced baby octopus is quite tasty or Toro over riced throughly mixed with Uni. This worked better than a similar dish I had elsewhere where they just served pieces of Toro and Uni over a bowl of rice. The chef here knows what he is doing and all the dishes work. There were no misses as far as I’m concerned.

Service is as you would expect and quite efficient. If you don’t do drink pairing and keep the drinks reasonable, the bill will be what was charged initially with a few dollars more, otherwise expect a large total. There is no tip so that’s always a good thing. Given the quality of food, it’s not overly expensive and I was full afterwards though I couldn’t resist getting ramen nearby since it’s close by to a really good ramen place.

I might come back in the summer to see how the menu changed.

There are only a handful of true sushiyas in New York City (if at all) and have nothing but praise for the young chef Nozomu. 

One of the best sourced with fish flown in from Japan including the most sort after uni on the planet, Hadate uni. 

Binchotan charcoal to sear your toro, no blowtorches here folks. Kudos to bringing true sushi artistry to NYC.

A delightful retreat into the universe of exquisite nigiri. Located next to Harbs in the Upper East Side, Noz brings out the elegance of nigiri art. Perhaps the hardest repertoire to confect in culinary history, chef Abe masterfully creates a sequence of nigiri portents, crafted and presented from his hands to you. My favorite highlight was without doubt the chu-toro (I am a toro fanatic). Prepare to spend an hour and a half- and be amazed by the nigiri tour de force. The chef himself will greet you upon departure- how gracious! Thank you Nozomu Abe and hopefully til soon.

Review titles: Authentic taste of Japan: Pure Ecstasy!

Review text: The cocktails at ZZ’s are top notch. They are cleaverly crafted by Garrett behind the bar who must start his day pretty early since he mixes his own drink bases, one mix for each cocktail creation, from scratch. ZZ’s has a nice collection of good rums, to their credit, I saw none of the “standard issue rums” that make everything taste the same. The result is a well balanced and flavorful cocktail that is incredibly good. Pair this with ambience of this small bar and you have a pretty unique find in New York City. ZZ’s is a find, a bar in our experience twice as good and more comfortable than the snooty fancy hotel bars (with the lousy standard issue rums) or the so-called “ranked 3rd best in the world bar” where everybody stood around because there was no place to sit. We’ll take cleaver & quaint over marketing mumbo jumbo every time. Go to ZZ’s!

Awesome little bar.  Loved how quaint and intimate it is.  The bartender handled his drinks like a work of art.  I'm sadly not big on seafood, but we ended up ordering food from Carbone next door and it was an evening I will never forget!

From the outside the place doesn't look like anything. You basically just see a bouncer. As soon as you get inside it's completely different. The place is small and cozy with a great bar. We ended up staying for hours trying out different drinks (which are all served in interesting ways) and the food, which is incredible tasty. Such an amazing experience!

I went to this restaurant with high expectations. The restaurant is very cozy and the four tables offer an exclusive environment.
Wine variety limited as it is mainly a cocktail bar, the food that I tried was good until the OWNER came to the restaurant with two more friends.
They were extremely loud and terribly rude to the other two tables and us. Half way our meal they wanted to START SMOKING when the other two couples had expressed their disapproval. As a person that firmly believes in NYC I reminded the owner that it was forbidden by NYC law, he said that he did not mind and that he 'knew' people at the NYPD... I could not believe what I as listening! 
He got very defensive and a bit aggressive, he was trying to "buy" us with free dinner so he could smoke!! A complete lack of respect to the food, wine, patrons and chefs!! We continued the argument until I said, we are leaving, at that very moment, in defiance, he lighted up the cigarette!! I could not believe it!!
One of his friends said, "oh, it must be because it's expensive for them (meaning us)" I was perplexed! 
What if... this was the case? If I had put all my savings to visit this place? The disappointment would have being even more disastrous...
I was informed that he (the owner) often does this, behavior wise, and also forces his employees to stay until 5 am and they have to breath the smoke... Can you imagine?
Please do not go and support the nepotism of this restaurant owner, this is New York and the options on responsible social owners are a lot!

The bouncer-type that checked me at the door had me wondering what I was getting myself into... but once inside I fell in love. The intimate dining room seats about 15 and the artisanal bar is the focal point here. The menu is small but focused. I loved everything, particularly the uni on toast. Did I mention the uni on toast?? My only caveat is its not inexpensive.. we were a party of 2, one round of cocktails, with 5 tapatizer dishes, the bill came too over $225 and... I was full but.. I could've eaten more. But its been a few weeks since I have dined there and I still think about it. Such is love...
Fantastic cocktails and amazing food. Certainly not cheap, but absolutely worth it. Great atmosphere and background music. Just brace yourself for coping with the ‘attitude’.

Went here with friends who are NYC locals and in the industry so we got red carpet treatment. The cocktails are based on a single flavor, ie: peanut butter, basil, pistachio, coconut, pineapple, etc....I started off with peanut butter, which wasn't what you'd expect it to be, but it did have just enough of a PB essence to be worthy of the name. Then I switched over to coconut which is served in...a coconut. Both drinks were very good. For snacks we were given clams to start -- hands down the best clams ever. Then we ordered the raw oysters -- best oysters I've ever eaten. You notice a trend here? The tuna toasts are also amazing -- mmmmmaybe not the best tuna tartar I've ever had but easily top 3. And to top it all off the lobster w/ avacado was the perfect finish to our pre-dinner snacks. It was the perfect beginning to what was an awesome night out with friends in the city. Make it yours too.

Review titles: Pls read - nepotistic owner - DON'T GO

Review text: My wife and I decided to stop in before we had dinner at Jane. I thought I read on one of the review sites that this was a two $ sign restaurant...I was wrong! We walked here from our hotel and were on the street that ZZ's was on but couldn't find it. Then I look to my left, see a small sign, and a guy in a black suit. I start to walk in and he asks if we have reservations...I say no...he says are we having dinner? I say no, just a drink...he says hold on a minute. He goes inside and comes back out and states that we can come in but only for 45 minutes as they are expecting reservations to start coming in. We can't resist so we head in. The hostess/waitress seats us at the table top counter along the wall. The place is dark (which I like!), and its us and about 12 other people. It only holds that many. Review titles: Small trendy delicious and amazingly expensive

Review text: What an awesome place. Only seats 10-14 people. Not much bigger than a studio apartment. Nice decor at this exclusive seafood place. Service was intimate and attentive. Drinks are large and fun cocktails in create casings for $20. We were given an aperitif as well. We started with the royale. We had ordered 2 of every oyster and clam. But for a "bit" more you can add Petrossian trout roe with bellinis. It was excellent. The uni toast was outstanding. Salty, creamy, and sweet. The mackerel was good but not on par with everything else. We opted for the tuna carpaccio with clams and foie gras. As decadent and smooth as it sounds. Expensive but worth it. Not an every day place but definitely worth the splurge.

After a brilliant start at the bar, our evening went downhill when we were seated in the dining room. We ordered three courses and then the short ribs for two. Waiter told us that wasn't enough food for the two of us- WHAT?
As each course came, hummus, octopus and pasta, the staff insisted in taking the dishes away, even as we were still eating them...we felt incredibly rushed and repeatedly had to tell them we weren't finished yet. Were they really trying to turn the tables at these prices? The short rib platter came out cold. When the waiter came by and we told him, he said they'd make us another new platter....except our platter came back over well done....so it seemed reheated, far from new. We ate a slice each and left the rest. Of course, in their rush to clean the table, no one noticed the platter was still basically full- and no one cared.
Desserts (they did bring us one extra dessert to celebrate our anniversary), we uniformly excellent.. They dropped the check without asking us...again...were they trying to turn the table.
This is far from the experience we expected to have coming to Crown Shy- Especially after the brilliant start in the bar area. We won't be back (and they won't care). Too bad.

I came here on a Wednesday night with several coworkers. The service was excellent but the appetizers and entrees were just so-so. One thing you don’t want to pass up is dessert – I’m not sure what the official name is, but they have an ice cream dish called satsuma orange that tastes like a homemade dreamcicle. It is also very loud inside and difficult to hear your dinner companions, and there is pulsating rap music throughout the place. The restaurant is very neat looking in the old AIG building, but nice decor, service, and dessert aside I would pass this one up and spend your money elsewhere.

Review titles: New restaurant with Michelin Star is worth trying

Review text:
This Emperor Needs Some Clothes 
Let’s start off by what is right. Landmark building, beautiful lighting & material fit out, friendly staff, mixology and stemware. A+ 
Small adjustments that would go along way: Improved wines and spirit knowledge and enthusiasm by server staff. 
Shortcoming: 
The food: smaller than necessary portions. 25% more food on the plate would justify the premium price points. Flavor and temperature control: razor clam carrots were lukewarm. Placing jalapeños on top of the oysters robs mineral quality and brininess of the oyster. That dish needs to be reconsidered immediately. 
Epic Failure 
The bathroom was strewn with paper towels giving it a sudden Port Authority chic. Hire an attendant to stay on top of tidiness and this problem is easily solved! 
Dessert: Cream puffs while featuring a delectable passion fruit filling were absolutely stale. The cream was liquidy and lacked proper consistency. 
Will I be back? Hopefully. I really want to experience this place in the future as much as I imagined I would.
Understated, simple dining room. Short menu. Really nice wine list. Service was really excellent (we had a great server); Somm could use some personality.

Came for a birthday lunch with very high expectations. Location is neat and nicely decorated, although it was cold for being January! We had the 3 course prix fixe and noticed all dishes had a bitter and burnt aftertaste. We loved the fluke crudo, but the crunchy wafer tasted a bit bitter. Not to mention the chicory salad with mozzarella, which was dominated by chicory and grapefruit, both very bitter. The stuffed pasta and the quail were good, but desserts were once again dominated by burnt caramel flavor. Service was slow for being a typical business lunch location.
Real NY place with wonderful food and service. Amazing cocktails. Really relaxing and fun place to visit.

Very cool, casual vibe. Atmosphere where there is “pressure” not to over dress. Ha ha. Well sort of. Food is great. It’s all about the appetizers. Cauliflower is out of this world, a tiny bit spicy. I split Branzino entree with friend. Also delicious. Definitely worth a visit.

My husband and I are foodies and we had the pre-fixe lunch. Rustic food, but creative, well-prepared and nicely presented. It was the holidays and raining outside, and the restaurant is minimalist in style, but they had nice holiday decorations so it felt a bit warmer and welcoming. The service was excellent. If you enjoy creative dishes and food, then it's worth a try. It's not super fancy, but that's not the intended vibe of this restaurant.

Expect a meal with an innovative blend of ingredients with brilliant flavors that create this masterpiece on a plate. The service was slightly laid back but in a very good way. Our waiter was attentive but relaxed, which created an easy atmosphere at the table. Pull apart olive bread with sour cream butter and sea salt, Yea-Delicious. Started with 3 small plates. Gruyere Fritter which are savory in ever sense. They look like churros and my mind wants to eat it expecting sweet cinnamon fried dough but its a savory mindf*ck. Salty gooey melty greyere cheese flows through this buttery-ish pastry. Awesome. The roasted carrot swimming in the razor clam foam, never would i thought clams and carrots but it works. Carrots cooked through with a slight char on the outside. Razor clam broth and foam bring a sea salt/salinity to the earthy charred carrots. Great idea. They honey squash with pomegranate was naturally sweet with that pop of fruit. Great presentations. Entrees were no exception. My friend ordered the Branzino. Roasted and shaved Brussel sprouts and shaved cucumber on to of a center split, 2 filet fresh catch. Cucumber was ever so slightly present which truly elevated the dish. I had the quail over farro. As we know quail is small and easily over cooked, this was a good size and portion and perfectly roasted. The jus was reminiscent of a beef broth but not as bold. Absorbed by the farro which brought its own semi cooked texture and flavors to blend perfectly with the quail. Dessert was honey ice box cake and banana ice cream with caramel popcorn aka craker jacks on top. I commend this restaurant for only serving Australian wines during this time of need. A portion of the wines go to the Koala hospital in NSW and for the Australian Red Cross. I started with a pinot noir from Adelaide Hills called "The Sabre", then a McLaren Vale Shiraz labeled Sherrah and finished with The Sticky Stump Jump by d'Arenberg. Cheers!

I can't even begin to explain how absolutely amazing the cocktails and food were at this restaurant. The service was EXCELLENT. I went there 2 weeks ago and I still think about that evening out every day. If you go there and you like Gin, you must try the "Resinate" shaken cocktail. I wasn't sure I would like it, but I ended up consuming 3 of them!

Finally, a restaurant with one Michelin Star in NYC that deserves it, and more.  The food, tthe room, the art, atmosphere, service and oh my goodness the food, have me wanting to return ASAP. This is Austrian with attitude and inspired flavours.  Of course, nothing...More

Well deserved Michelin star, any foodie should try!

Terrific contemporary Austrian cuisine in a neat and cool setting with courteous and helpful service. Deliciously creative. The lobster followed by schnitzel with a bottle of flavourful Riesling provided perfect balance. Rounded off with strudel for extra authenticity! A real pleasure.

Review titles: Service and food shone equally bright!

Review text:

The atmosphere is really classy and really i will back soon on my next visit to NYC.

Instead of going for the full tasting menu we came here to enjoy their dessert only tasting menu. Understandably, this is served in the bar rather than in the main dining area. Despite this, the service - of both the food and wine - was from the same staff and at the same level as the dining room. 
The desserts themselves were all very distinct, so offered a great journey through the pastry section's creations. Of course Jungsik's signature mini banana dessert featured along the way. The amount of work and delicate touch both in terms of the actual techniques involved as well as the balance of flavours was evident in each and every dish. Even the more classical dessert, their take on the classic Paris-Brest, was particularly good.
All in all an excellent experience and next time we'll be back to enjoy what the rest of the kitchen has to offer!

We had the season menu. The lobster and cod dishes were absolutely superb. This is a world class restaurant and was arguably the greatest meal I have had in NYC. The signature cocktails were also fantastic. We will be back to try some of the signature dishes at the bar with cocktails.
